TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that . . .

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the ``joint high frequency stations'' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines.
This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
4. The ``joint U.S.-Australian'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 125 citizens), Jones (from 304 citizens), Macklin (from 498 citizens) and Stone (from 245 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia
2. ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products,
3. ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation, (electron beam, X ray etc.)
4. ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government during the recent election campaign, your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base in the 1987 budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag incorrectly proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable house will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs, one of which will be the present Australian national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 17 citizens) and Reid (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider that the Federal Government's decision to have Telecom charge for the cost of `Directory Assistance' inquiries will greatly disadvantage, the sick elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the Government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for `Directory Assistance' inquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hill (from 204 citizens) and Schacht (from 208 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: Honourable President and senators in Parliament assembled. We, your humble petitioners pray that, in accordance with the wishes of a substantial number of the people of Australia, the Australia Card Bill be rejected, and we in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled. Your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 145 citizens), Macklin (from 28 citizens), Puplick (from 20 citizens) and Reid (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hill (from seven citizens) and Jones (from 329 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Australia Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in com- bating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Grants: Northern Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the granting of certain areas of land in connection with the Jawoyn (Katherine Area) land claim. Specifically, petitioners request that the following lands not be granted.
(a) That part of the Katherine Gorge National Park comprising the Katherine Gorge system and adjacent developed areas and all areas to the north thereof, including Edith Falls;
(b) The whole catchment areas of those sites under consideration for utilisation as future water supply for the Katherine township and, in particular, the catchments of McAddens and Dorothy Creeks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs does not make a land grant, under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, as recommended by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in his report of 6th October 1987, but that he heeds the desire of the undersigned citizens of Australia, thereby excluding from grant, the areas defined above.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Highrise Hotel: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows.
That we are totally opposed to the imminent construction of a highrise hotel on the parkland area between the Boulevard and the CAGA Centre and Akuna Street and Allara Street.
Your petitioners therefore request that the development of this hotel not proceed and the further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) left Australia on 30 October for official duties in Egypt, the United Kingdom and Japan. He will return on 14 November. During his absence, I am pleased to say, Senator Richardson will be Acting Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Questions in this chamber should be directed to Senator Richardson in relation to Mr John Brown's portfolio in the usual way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Puplick moving that the Senate take note of the statement.

The purpose of seeking the suspension of Standing Orders is to allow us to discuss the matter in the Minister's statement-namely, the departure once again from Australia of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), who has been frequently called the Minister for having a good time. He has struck once again and undoubtedly intends to do his bit to add to the nation's deficit. In every sense it can be said that the organ grinder has shot through, leaving the monkey in charge of the barrel. Therefore, it is of some value to suspend the Standing Orders to debate Mr Brown's continued travel plans. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to find out what is the cost of this trip. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to discuss precisely what the Minister intends to do in Egypt, apart from renewing old acquaintances with Cleopatra and undoubtedly indulging himself in the pleasures of a Nile voyage.

Senator Gareth Evans-On an inevitable point of order, Mr President: In the guise of identifying what will be the subject matters of the debate if Standing Orders are suspended, Senator Puplick is manifestly canvassing matters of substance and ought to be sat down.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now listening to a repeat of what happened a few days ago. I remind Senator Puplick that he can speak only as to why Standing Orders should be suspended.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to discuss exactly what the Minister intends to do in the United Kingdom. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to ascertain why he is visiting London for the fourth time. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to discuss why the Minister is visiting Tokyo for the third time and what he intends to do there. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to discuss whether the Minister's behaviour will be the same as the behaviour in which he indulged himself between 17 July and 15 August 1985 when he visited Athens, Rome, Milan, London, Edinburgh, New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco at a total cost of $70,000. If Standing Orders are suspended we will be able to work out whether the Minister will be indulging in the same behaviour--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Puplick is stretching beyond tolerable limits the substance and spirit of your ruling in this place. It is a bit of vulgar, populist grandstanding of the kind that ought not to be permitted consonant with the dignity of this place and your position in the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Puplick and I remind him of what I said earlier.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly cognisant of your warning, Mr President. If Standing Orders are suspended, we will be able to ascertain whether, when the Minister is in the United Kingdom or in Japan, which are, after all, not particularly cheap destinations, he will indulge in the same behaviour as he did when he was in--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-I take a point of order, Mr President. I repeat: Every time Senator Puplick opens his mouth in the guise of identifying what will be able to be debated, he canvasses matters of substance by way of parenthesis, additional sentences, comments, cheap laughs and cheap remarks. It is not to be tolerated, Mr President, if we are to maintain any decorum, decency or dignity in this chamber.

Senator Chaney-Mr President, on the point of order: This is the third time the Minister has interrupted Senator Puplick before he has really had time to resume his stride after the first interruption. For this Minister to be suggesting that populist grandstanding is out of order in this place is farcical. In any event, quite clearly the honourable senator should be allowed to develop his argument and should not be interrupted in the way that the Minister has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair finds itself in a very difficult position. I think Senator Puplick is nearing the end of his remarks as to why Standing Orders should be suspended to move the motion today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal reason for seeking to move for the suspension of Standing Orders is to allow the Senate to discuss a matter of significance, namely the protection of the threatened public revenue. One would have thought that the public revenue is something the Government is anxious to protect. One would have thought that the Government itself would have been scandalised that, in London, Rome, New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, a Minister of the Crown could spend $15,000 on limousine hire.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-Mr President, I take a point of order. Not once in Senator Puplick's remarks today has he addressed himself to the question of the timing, which, I submit to you, is the only relevant consideration. There is ample opportunity for the kinds of matters that Senator Puplick is claiming need to be canvassed to be canvassed through the ordinary procedures of this place. Mr President, if one is to make a case for the suspension of Standing Orders, what is relevant is to point to the urgency, the immediacy and the relevance of the time factor in determining why Standing Orders should be suspended. Mr President, I put it to you that unless Senator Puplick addresses himself immediately to that question, he ought to be sat down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Puplick to take careful note of the point just made by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Wood-Mr President, may I move that the question be put?

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to be able to accommodate the honourable senator.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conscious of the urgency, the relevance and the immediacy of the matters which have to be addressed and I have no doubt that, in proper discharge of their duties, Senator Walsh would be able to inform us right at this very minute how much the trip will cost, what is the purpose of the trip, whether there will be--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Puplick is acting in manifest disregard of the matter which you just drew to his attention. Every time he gets to his feet he continues the same sentence where he left off. Mr President, he is calling you and this chamber into contempt, and I ask that you deal with him accordingly.

Senator Chaney-Mr President, on the point of order: I think the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate has made the mistake of interrupting Senator Puplick so frequently as to make any assessment of whether he is developing that argument almost impossible. The point is that Senator Puplick is addressing why this matter should be debated now rather than later and he has been touching on the fact that the Minister for Finance, who carries around vast amounts of information about the affairs of the Queensland Government, no doubt would have equally copious amounts of information available to him about the affairs of his colleague the Hon. John Brown. Mr President, I submit that the proper course for your dealing with these endless points of order from Senator Evans is to allow Senator Puplick to develop his argument long enough for you to form a judgment as to whether the ruling is being followed. If you form the judgment that it is not being followed, no doubt you will sit the senator down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In relation to the point of order, I have been listening carefully to what Senator Puplick has been saying and I think he is about to conclude his argument. If he does not, I will accept the advice that I have just received from the Leader of the Opposition and conclude the remarks.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, the urgency of this matter relates to the proper control of financial and public expenditure. I would have thought that the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would have shared the concern which all honourable senators have, for the protection of the revenue and that they would not have been prepared to countenance a situation in which a Minister takes three trips at a cost of $178,000 or $1,658 a day; that he manages to spend $592 a day on accommodation and food--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Puplick is manifestly canvassing matters of substance and he is not going to the procedural question, which is the sole question before the Chair. Mr President, I submit further to you that, if you do not sit him down and if he continues this particular course, you will be acting in a way which is manifestly inconsistent with your capacity to carry on the affairs of this chamber. Mr President, it has got to that point and I suggest that you do not allow it to go any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Puplick to conclude his remarks.

—Of course, the money will have been spent if one is not in a position to make judgment about the appropriateness of this matter. One is entitled to know, as of today, the purpose of yet another visit to Egypt, the United Kingdom and Japan; to know whether the scandals of the Minister's overseas expenditures are to be repeated; whether the sort of expenditure of $592 a day on food and accommodation for the Minister and his party is to be continued; whether the hire of limousines at $2,900 for three days for junketing between Rome, Florence and Milan is to be re-peated--

—Mr President, the reason for the urgency of debating this matter is to know whether there is anything left in the biscuit tin or whether the Minister has cleared it out before we have had a chance to examine this matter. Consequently this is a matter of urgency. The Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate should understand that this Parliament, in seeking to take note of a statement that he has made, is entitled to certain information. He ought to be aware that, if he comes to this chamber and makes a statement about the behaviour of Government Ministers-that is to say, their travel arrangements-the Parliament is entitled to raise questions. In the past, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has manifestly demonstrated his incompetence to protect adequately and properly the public revenue on his frequent and expensive overseas tours. If that is not a matter of some substance which the Parliament is entitled to debate, the Minister has redefined what responsibility in terms of public expenditure means. As Senator Chaney has rightly said, the figures would be available from Senator Walsh--
—Order! Senator Puplick, you were in order until that point. I think you are repeating the arguments that you used before. Have you concluded your remarks, Senator Puplick?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PUPLICK

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not concluded my remarks, Mr President. If the Minister wishes to create a situation in which one has to seek formally to suspend Standing Orders in order to take note of a ministerial statement, he brings this procedure upon himself. The Standing Orders require me to demonstrate why it is that they should be suspended-that is, what it is that is urgent, what it is that is of pressing public interest in this matter. Mr President, if I am not able to put forward a simple statement of what this side of the chamber believes to be a matter of substance, the persuasive argument as to why Standing Orders should be suspended becomes very difficult. All I am attempting to do, with the added constant assistance of the Minister at the table, is to put down quite clearly the argument that there is a significant question of public policy involved in Mr Brown's overseas travel arrangements.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-I take a point of order, Mr President. I suggest that the matter in issue is not whether the question is one of substance, although, of course there may be different views about that, or whether it is a significant matter of public policy. The question before the Senate at the moment is whether the matter is of such urgency, as to the question of time, as to require that the Standing Orders of this place be suspended. I put it to you very strongly, Mr President, that that is the only matter that it is appropriate for Senator Puplick to canvass. Every time he gets into questions of substance or the alleged significance of the nature of matters in issue, he is acting in a way which is contrary to his or your obligations in this place to keep debate under control.

Senator Chaney-On the point of order, Mr President: The Minister announced to the Senate a few minutes ago that his colleague Mr Brown had set off on yet another Government trip. It may be thought that that is a matter which could be debated at some time in the future. The point which has been developed by Senator Puplick is that the travel record of this particular Minister is one that the Opposition would regard as grossly extravagant expenditure.
Senator Stone-Self-indulgent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to Friday's speech by the Treasurer which seemed to indicate that the Government may be having second thoughts about its refusal to consider a review of economic policy settings but that it would maintain the `wait and see' approach. While the Government appears ready to ignore the warnings of the Opposition and the Senate, I draw the Minister's attention to the views of Mr Ross Gittins, an economic commentator, whose work the Minister has previously praised. In today's Sydney Morning Herald he wrote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to argue that the outlook for the domestic economy will not differ substantially from that foreshadowed in the Budget is to invite ridicule.
Further, he says:
Does it take an atom bomb to make the Treasurer admit that his Budget may have been overtaken by events? Mr Keating and his advisers seems to be suffering from an overdose of Valium.
Will the Minister agree that a `do nothing' policy is no longer appropriate and will the Government review its economic policy settings as a matter of urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Keating's position and that of the Government is that we are not going to be rushed into any precipitant response to the present situation until we have a much better picture as to what the longer term outlook will be in response to the stock market events of the last fortnight. The Treasurer has said-and I repeat on his behalf-that we will act as appropriate when it becomes necessary to do so. We will not jump into any course of action in a situation where we do not believe that action is justified or we do not believe that the parameters within which we are so acting are sufficiently clearly settled to make it possible to make sound judgments about what the basic response, if any, should be. We have taken the view that, so far as our short term prospects are concerned, we do expect continued improvements in the balance of payments consistent with our Budget forecasts of a fall in the current account deficit in 1987-88 to $11.5 billion or around 4 per cent of gross domestic product.

ANSWER.PARA: Again, we believe that our policies of firm fiscal and wage restraint, which are in marked contradistinction to those-particularly on the fiscal side-which are applicable in the United States and which demand quick and firm remedial action there, provide an effective strategy for the long haul and that they will and should remain in place. This year, Commonwealth outlays as a proportion of the economy will fall by 2.5 per cent. This is the largest ever cut and it follows a decline of one per cent in 1986-87. Present expectations are that average weekly earnings over the course of this financial year will, in fact, come in under the present Budget estimate. Critics who argue that we should tighten fiscal policy are really-as we see it at the moment-advocating essentially a recession and higher unemployment. They are advocating a knee jerk reaction before any worthwhile assessment of policy needs can be made. Obviously, we are continuing to monitor very closely the effects of the stock market crash on the Australian economy so that we can make some judgment as to whether the market has stabilised, as appears possible, but that is a judgment that is premature at this stage. We will make any policy adjustments that may be indicated as necessary as those developments unfold and we will not be rushed into any earlier action than that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer, which can be summarised as saying that the Government will not be rushed into action. I note also that the Treasurer is calling upon the United States Government to take action-not to wait but to take action now. I ask whether the Minister therefore disagrees with another of Mr Gittins's conclusions, namely:

QUESTION.PARA: We are already deep in the poo, deeper than almost any other industrial country.
Why is it correct for the United States to be told to take action by our Treasurer but, in fact, a `do-nothing, wait and see' attitude is appropriate for him?

TALK.START.PARA: —The distinction between the United States and Australian economies-which I think even Senator Chaney would be acutely aware of-is that the Budget deficit in the United States is currently running at over $150 billion and that is in stark contrast to a situation in this country where, as is well known to everyone including, I would have thought, Senator Chaney, we have achieved a situation of budgetary balance. There is an urgent and overwhelming need for a show of fiscal responsibility in the United States and it is to that particular context that the Treasurer was quite properly referring.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT OF JAPANESE STAFF BY DUTY FREE SHOP

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to media reports that the management of a duty free shop in Surfers Paradise has replaced some of its staff with Japanese tourists? Can the Minister advise how many Japanese are being employed by this shop and what type of visa each has? What are the conditions attached to the visas and, if work is permitted while these people are in Australia, are they expected to move regularly and undertake casual work only? Is the Government concerned that foreign nationals are taking the place of Australian workers, putting Australians out of work and on to unemployment benefit? Would the Minister's Department encourage businesses to assist Australian employees to gain sufficient language skills to serve foreign customers, rather than seek our foreign tourists to perform these duties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question. Yes, my attention has been drawn to the media report that he mentioned. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has advised me that, to ensure the continued growth in Japanese tourism, service providers have recognised the need for their businesses to have a knowledge of Japanese language and culture. The extent to which this need can be met by Japanese temporary residents as opposed to Australians is presently the subject of discussions between the Department and the tourism and hospitality industry. The store in question, referred to in Senator Colston's question, employs seven Japanese staff of a total staffing of 17. Initial inquiries by the Department indicate that four of the seven are working holidaymakers. The Department is separately reviewing the employment and entry conditions of the other three.

ANSWER.PARA: The working holidaymakers scheme is reciprocal. It allows young Japanese people, usually aged between 18 and 25, to holiday in Australia and to supplement their living costs with casual employment, usually for no more than three months in six. Australians travelling in Japan benefit from the same arrangement. There is a parallel arrangement with a number of other countries. However, the Government is concerned about foreign nationals appearing to take the place of Australian workers in this instance. I will refer the latter part of Senator Colston's question to Minister Young.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said in her answer that these people are working holidaymakers. Can the Minister advise how many Japanese are in Australia on working holidaymaker visas, and how many Australians are in Japan on the same type of visa?
—I will have to take that question on notice.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Local Government. In the light of the Government's moves towards reform of the Australian Constitution, does the Minister intend to take early action to have local government recognised in the Australian Constitution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to answer that question. It is certainly the Government's policy to pursue the recognition of local government within the Constitution. Two advisory committees to the Constitutional Commission have already commented in this regard. The Advisory Committee on the Distribution of Powers has recommended against. It has opted for the status quo, probably because of the complexity of determining the specific distribution of powers. However, the Advisory Committee on Trade and National Economic Management has acknowledged that local government is part and parcel of elected government in this country, is a very important part of government processes in the delivery of services to Australians and is very important in the economic development of this country, and so has recommended in favour.

ANSWER.PARA: My office is currently preparing a response to the two advisory committee reports. Perhaps with the exception of the honourable senator's State, I am already receiving from most States many letters from local government supporting the recognition of local government in the Constitution. Of course, this issue will be the subject of final recommendation by the Constitutional Commission by the middle of next year, and the Government will look at that recommendation accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women to comments by the Director of the Business Regulation Review Unit, Dr Allan Moran, which questioned the Government's subsidisation of child care. Does the Minister agree with Dr Moran's claim that the present system subsidises the affluent and that, almost without exception, private services are more efficient? In light of Dr Moran's comments, does the Government have any plans to review its commitment to subsidised child care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not agree with the observations which are reported as having been made by Dr Moran, the Director of the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit. Specifically, the Government will continue its long-standing commitment to supporting accessible community based child care services. Next year we will be funding 110,000 places compared with just 46,000 places when we came to office. There is no substance to the claim that the present system subsidises the affluent. Families with incomes in excess of $32,000 a year pay full fees and funded child care centres receive operational subsidies only for these children. Funding of child care via tax deductibility rather than direct grants would be inappropriate because such a measure would be regressive in providing assistance only to those with a substantial income who can afford the initial outlay for child care prior to the end of the taxation year and, of course, it would not assist low income families.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the claim of Dr Moran that private child care services are more efficient than public child care services, I do not think he is comparing like with like when he makes that claim. Private services do not cater significantly for the nought to two-year-old age group, tend to open for shorter hours and do not meet the Commonwealth's objectives of providing child care in areas with the highest need.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN: GRANTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I understand that the Office of the Status of Women has made operational grants of $15,000 each to the National Council of Women of Australia, the Country Women's Association (CWA), the Federation of Business and Professional Women and the Women's Electoral Lobby, but a comparatively huge sum of $40,000 to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) Working Women's Centre, which is almost three times the size of the grant made to the CWA. —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister advise what are the relative memberships of the first four national organisations which I mentioned and the actual membership of the ACTU Working Women's Centre?

—I do not have that information with me. Certainly it represents a significant section of opinion amongst women living in rural and regional Australia and as such it certainly has a very legitimate claim for a grant of this kind. But I do not think it is appropriate to make a direct comparison between a non-government organisation such as the CWA and an organisation which is set up to serve the needs of working women in a systematic fashion.
—It is a government organisation, is it?
—Why not?

—The interjections with which one has to contend are too silly for words. I would have thought that even the recently arrived Senator Stone would know the status of the ACTU without asking questions. It is not a government organisation. The work of the Working Women's Centre is different in character from that carried out by voluntary organisations. For example, it is not a voluntary organisation that employs staff and so on and so forth. I have undertaken to get for Senator Bishop the details of the application of the funds which have been supplied to the ACTU Working Women's Centre. I can get details such as the number of women who are members of unions affiliated with the ACTU, and I will see what information we have on record about the number of members of the organisations mentioned.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen an editorial in the West Australian of last Thursday calling for the removal of a supposed anomaly between the treatment of profits and losses on share trading? Is there in fact an anomaly, or is the editorial in effect arguing for the subsidisation of some share traders' losses by other taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indeed seen the editorial in the West Australian of last Thursday, the most relevant section of which states:

ANSWER.PARA: As the tax law stands, short-term share profits will be subject to taxation, but there is no provision for share losses to be offset against them.

The general thrust of the editorial went on to develop the argument that share losses should be deductible against income from any source; at least, I think that is the point it was trying to make. The point made in the passage I quoted is correct so far as the capital gains tax is concerned. But there has long been a provision in the tax legislation under which people who buy and sell shares, and indeed also some other classes of people, can be classified by the Commissioner of Taxation as a trader. Having been classified as a trader, they pay tax on their profits from share trading just as they would pay tax on any other income. Under the capital gains tax legislation, only the real gains on share trading activities are assessable as income-of course, that is a major concession, particularly if shares are held over a very long period-whereas, if profits are to be classified as income earned by a share trader, tax is applied to the nominal income, not the real income.

I think the point that the editorial was trying to make was to complain that those people who are in fact share traders and always have been share traders but who have conned the Australian Taxation Office into accepting the proposition that they are not share traders, now want to become share traders again. In other words, they want to change the rules after the game has finished, or after the game is at least halfway through. Insofar as particular transactions are concerned, they want to change the rules after the game is finished. The West Australian newspaper, not surprisingly-I say `not surprisingly' given the general lack of intellectual rigour normally displayed in its editorials-has taken up the cudgels on behalf of these people who have until now spent all of their lives posing as people who were not share traders and now want to be classified, for the purpose of taxable income, as share traders because they have had some windfall losses on their shareholdings.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: USE OF AGENT ORANGE IN VIETNAM

Is the Minister aware that the 2,4,5-T used in Vietnam contained on average approximately 20 times the level of 2,3,7,8 tetracholo dibenzo dioxane (TCDD), with some samples of 2,4,5-T containing up to several hundred times the levels of TCDD now permitted in Australia? Does the Minister recognise that TCDD is a known mutagen and carcinogen? Does the Minister also accept that all recognised world authorities, such as the International Agency for Research on Cancer, believe that a linear/no threshold relationship exists between the level of exposure to a mutagen and the risk of effects arising, such as abortion and birth defects? Does it not therefore follow that the conclusion of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam that none of these health effects-abortions, birth defects and cancers-arose as a consequence of exposure to Agent Orange in Vietnam, is patently not supported by the evidence or by accepted scientific theory? Finally, will the Minister therefore advise her colleague the Minister for Defence that the Hogg inquiry must find that one of the principal conclusions of the Evatt inquiry was wrong?
—I do not have the detailed information required to answer the honourable senator's question. I will take that question on notice.

—I am not aware of any decision to send police to Christmas Island. I will check on that. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the Minister to clear up a point for me. He referred to the sacking of Christmas Island workers. My question specifically related to the sacking of the nine-member Christmas Island Assembly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. To what extent have the Bjelke-Petersen Government's economic policies been successful in improving Queensland's performance relative to other comparable States in the area of unemployment, particularly since the Queensland National Party ridded itself of the Liberals at the 1983 State election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1983 Queensland election, the Premier said:

ANSWER.PARA: We will give the style of leadership that generates business and investment confidence. A style that creates jobs and job security.

At that time Queensland had 15 per cent of the nation's unemployed. On the most recent figures, it now has 19.2 per cent of the nation's unemployed. So, the answer to Senator Gietzelt's question about the extent to which the Bjelke-Petersen Government has been successful in improving Queensland's performance relative to other States is that not only has it had no success at all, but it has been very successful in doing the opposite-that is, bringing in an economic outcome relatively worse than any other State.

The most recent unemployment rate for Queensland is 9.3 per cent, which is the highest in Australia. For all but three of the 48 months for which the present Queensland Government has been in office, Queensland's unemployment rate has been above the national average. In this year, 1987, it has been the highest or equal highest in no less than eight out of those nine months. Let us look at the number of people involved by a direct comparison with the State of Victoria which, of course, has almost two-thirds more people in the work force than Queensland. Victoria has only 80,000 people on unemployment benefits compared with 101,000 in Queensland. So Victoria has 65 per cent more people in the work force but 20 per cent fewer people on unemployment benefits than Queensland.

The normal response to those facts is to say that recorded unemployment is high in Queensland because people move into that State because of its climatic advantages. That argument, too, has been blown out of the water, because in fact in the financial year 1985-86 there was a net loss of some 3,400 people from Queensland in the 15 to 24 age group; that is, the young working age group. The reason for that, presumably, is that Queensland also has, in almost all months, the highest youth unemployment rate of all States.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of the Senate to the presence in my gallery of the Hon. John Johnson, President of the Legislative Council of New South Wales. It is a pleasure to welcome him as a fellow parliamentary Presiding Officer and also as a colleague.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Did Austrade advise the Australian companies of these opportunities to tender less than 14 days before tenders closed when Austrade apparently was aware of the general possibilities of these tenders for about four months? To overcome this negligence, did the Austrade office in Tokyo then send the tender documents-written in Japanese with a short English translation to parts of them-direct to the Australian companies without involving either the Australian offices of Austrade or the appropriate industry associations to suggest any translation or assistance in completing these tender documents? Will the Government undertake a post mortem inquiry as to why this happened and to establish appropriate mechanisms to ensure that this situation does not recur and that Austrade's resources are effectively mobilised to give timely advice and effective assistance to Australian companies in their trade dealings with non-English speaking nations?

—One of the nice things about having this job is that Senator Lewis asks me questions. One of the unattractive features of losing it is that he is not likely to ask me questions any more. Senator Lewis gave me notice of the last question he asked me and therefore I had a reasonably comprehensive reply. This time he did not, so I do not have a completely comprehensive reply. But I do have a note here which appears to go to the main point of the question which asked whether it was correct that Austrade sent these notices out only 14 days before the event. It would appear from this note that the answer to that is no. It says: Over 1,500 notices were scrutinised and details on 307 items were sent over a four-month period to 65 Australian companies. Nearly all items were in the medical and scientific instrument fields. It may well be true that some notices were sent out only 14 days before the relevant date, but it appears not to be correct that that was the norm. In regard to the other parts of the question on language problems and recurrence, I will have to take the question on notice and supply an answer as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOINT EXERCISES WITH THE UNITED STATES NAVY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In the light of the Institute for Policy Studies-Greenpeace International document entitled The Nuclear Arms Race at Sea, tabled in the Senate on 29 October, I ask: How can the Government justify frequent joint exercises with the United States nuclear navy outside Australia's area of direct military interest as defined in the 1987 defence White Paper? Is it a fact that in 1985-86, 12 joint exercises were undertaken between the Australian defence forces and the United States defence forces totalling a cost of $43.5m? Is it a fact that of the 36 combined exercises with all other countries, including those 12 with the United States, precisely half were conducted outside Australia's area of direct military interest? Is it true that three of the exercises in the 1985-86 Silent Pearl series involved the Australian Defence Force (ADF) in chasing United States nuclear attack submarines off Hawaii? Are not such exercises superfluous to ADF needs and designed to suit United States naval requirements? Would not Australia's defence needs be better served by exercising within our region and with conventional forces rather than nuclear forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Combined exercises improve the competence of the Australian Defence Force and our national defence capabilities. They also improve the effectiveness of the Australian and United States forces should combined military operations, including operations in our area, ever become a necessity. Participation in each combined exercise is considered on its merits in the context of the benefits it provides to Australia and the policies set out in the defence policy information paper which was tabled on 19 March. Exercises with the United States Navy in particular provide valuable opportunities for training with advanced technology units of our allies. The opportunity does not otherwise readily exist for the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force to exercise with such highly capable forces.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the specific points raised by Senator Vallentine, in 1985-86, 13 exercises were conducted with the United States, either as bilateral or multilateral exercises. The cost of these exercises was $48.2m. Of the 36 exercises conducted with other countries, half were conducted outside Australia's area of direct military interest; eight of these were in Malaysia and Singapore and involved Australian forces based at Butterworth. Three Silent Pearl exercises were conducted and they involved gaining experience in tracking nuclear powered submarines. Apart from the inherent greater speed of nuclear submarines over conventional submarines, there is no difference in the training value obtained in exercising with nuclear powered or capable forces as opposed to conventionally powered forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I refer the Minister to his recent Press release giving details of the domestic travelling allowance costs of Ministers in the year ending 30 June 1987. I now ask the Minister: Why has he failed to supply this information? Will he now provide the Senate with the details?

—As Senator Short has said, it is true that when I released details of domestic travel allowance I also included, for the information of the public, the days of overseas travel of Ministers. Senator Short asks me to confirm whether that figure amounted to 521. I have no reason to doubt his arithmetic. However, if he wishes I can confirm whether he has added up correctly because I assume that we are working off the same figures.
—We know about the Liberal Party's figures.

—Senator Walsh remembers Liberal Party miscalculations in terms of adding things up. I would have thought that this figure was checked very carefully. I do not know whether Mr Carlton assisted the honourable senator on this matter but I will assume that his figure is accurate. He raised the question of publishing the costs of overseas travel. Normally they are published on an annual basis. When I took over the portfolio and when it was first brought to my attention that the figures had not been published for some time, I asked for them to be collated for publication. That series of collations is still occurring. I am in no way obstructing the publication of those figures. When the Department has them available, they will be published. I do not regard it as the absolute highest priority within the Department at the moment. We have already published the figures for domestic travel allowance and the official car costs. As the third leg of the trifecta this can be expected certainly before Parliament gets up and, hopefully, even this week. I have not checked the progress of the figures in the last few days, but they will be published until, I hope, the end of financial year 1986-87.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AEROSPACE TECHNOLOGIES OF AUSTRALIA PTY LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Following the sale of Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd, formerly the Government Aircraft Factories in Port Melbourne, what steps have been taken to ensure that employees have not been adversely affected by the change in ownership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know of Senator Zakharov's interest in this area. I make the following points to allay those fears: The ownership of the Government Aircraft Factories was transferred to the government owned company Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd on 8 October 1987. The majority of the Government Aircraft Factories employees are being transferred to Aerospace Technologies and will be covered by industrial awards which are similar to the Public Service awards. In addition, Public Service Act staff transferred to the company are subject to mobility provisions which provide for the following: the retention of accumulated entitlements such as sick leave, recreation leave, long service leave and access to the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund; the right to apply for and appeal against the filling of vacancies in the Public Service on the same basis as the existing Public Service Act employees; the right to re-enter the Public Service should their employment with Aerospace Technologies be terminated for any reason other than criminal conviction, retirement, resignation or invalidity retirement; and finally, the right to apply for re-entry into the Public Service on action taken by Aerospace Technologies which would significantly impact on their career prospects.

ANSWER.PARA: Those Government Aircraft Factories employees not selected for transfer to Aerospace Technologies are to be given a choice of redeployment within the Department of Defence or accepting a voluntary retrenchment package. Details of how individuals are affected by the change in ownership have been widely circulated and counselling sessions for employees have been arranged by both the Department and the company.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. In answer to a question from Senator Panizza in this place last Thursday, the Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is true that this year, and following the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, a new system of distribution throughout the country on a much more equitable basis, a needs basis, was introduced.

It is my understanding that this statement is misleading. Is it not true that the current funding arrangements are on a largely per capita and only a part needs basis? Can the Minister clarify or correct her apparently misleading statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am at a loss to understand Senator Calvert's question because I think the answer that I gave last week to Senator Panizza was absolutely correct in emphasising the needs basis that follows a very extensive inquiry by Professor Self. Professor Self travelled throughout Australia and spoke with local government in all areas of the country and, as a result, brought forward a report which I would recommend for reading to both Senator Calvert and Senator Panizza. In fact, I offered Senator Panizza-I extend that invitation to Senator Calvert-a full briefing of the new arrangements of local government funding. It is the first year of operation and it is a fairly complex statistical procedure. I would certainly offer the services of officers of my Department to explain it to either of those honourable senators or any other Opposition senator who is interested to follow up the issue that Senator Calvert has raised.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am more than happy to follow up the Minister's invitation, but the Minister said, and it is in Hansard, that funding is on a needs basis, when in fact I am led to believe that it is mostly on a per capita basis and partly on a needs basis. I am asking the Minister to clarify the position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to explain the full procedure and it would be much more appropriate if we were to go through the procedures in detail.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Reynolds is replying to a supplementary question.
—Sold out north Queensland again.

—If Senator Boswell would care to have some information about the numbers of councils in north Queensland which will benefit over the next six years by between a 20 per cent and a 40 per cent increase in local government funding, I would be happy to provide that answer. I repeat to Senator Calvert, and to other Opposition senators who have suddenly displayed an incredible interest in local government, and I welcome that interest, that it is a procedure that involves partly per capita and partly needs. It is a new system which the majority of local authorities have welcomed because it is a more equitable process of distribution. It cuts out many of the questionable practices over many years. There has been a history of capital cities getting more recognition and of certain rural areas getting particular recognition. The process is equitable and has been accepted by local authorities throughout the country. I commend Opposition senators to sit down with officers of my Department and to take the time to understand the full implications.

—Is the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer aware of recent calls by Mr John Elliott for the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax? Is the Government persuaded that a broad-based consumption tax ought to be introduced and that the tax mix should be shifted from the income tax base to the consumption tax base?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Liberal Party President's comments on a broad-based consumption tax-indeed, I am aware of quite a few comments that Mr Elliott has made recently. I am also aware of the fact that the Liberal Party thought that it had a problem when it had John Valder. It has a much bigger problem now. It will not be long before the Liberals are saying, `Come back, John Valder'. On the policy question of a broad-based consumption tax or general consumption tax, it was, as Senator Devlin will remember, looked at very seriously by this Government in 1985. Ultimately a decision was made not to proceed with it, for two principal reasons. The first was that some people had doubts whether there would be adequate compensation to low income groups or people who are dependent on welfare benefits. The second was an apparent lack of general community support, which was apparent among both the business sector, or managerial sector, and the wage earning sector. In those circumstances there was a significant risk that agreements to discount wage claims for the consequential consumer price index increase would not be fully effective and that therefore it would touch off a wage-price spiral.

ANSWER.PARA: Those were the Government's reasons for rejecting what Mr Elliott is now proposing. It is not clear what Mr Howard's reason or Senator Stone's reason for rejecting it are, except that Senator Stone has done a 180-degree turn on yet another issue since 1985 when he said on the Today television program on 2 July 1985:
I've always made quite plain my view that a broadly-based consumption tax is a thoroughly desirable thing to have. It's desirable on a number of grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Treasurer said that.
—He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The second bad point about the present wholesale sales tax is that because it has a number of different rates within it, governments have effectively decided that some purchases are good and other purchases are bad. I don't believe that governments have any right to make those decisions.

Senator Chaney reminded me that also at about the same time the Treasurer was advocating a broad-based consumption tax. That is true, and I have already said so, and have already given the principal reasons why the Government backed away from it. Why Senator Stone has backed away from it is not at all clear because, first, he is not very concerned about what happens to the poor and, secondly, he believes-quite wrongly, I believe-that one does not have to worry about wage demands and that the power of the unions, of organised labour or of whatever one likes to call it, can be completely destroyed in a very short time and therefore that is not a relevant consideration to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Local Government follows the answer she gave to the questions from Senator Calvert. Does the Minister know what percentage of local government funds is disbursed on a per capita basis and what percentage is disbursed on a needs basis, and, if so, what are those percentages?

—I thank Senator Chaney for his question. Looking at the per capita basis we are looking at a 30 per cent figure, but the remainder of funding is distributed on a needs basis. I repeat that it is a very complex procedure; it is a procedure which I do not propose at this stage to outline in detail to the Senate. I am more than happy to outline it to the Senate at such time as there is the opportunity for a full debate on this question. It is very important that Opposition senators acknowledge and recognise that local government funding distribution over many years has not been done on an equitable basis. It is now done on a much more equitable basis. The per capita basis is one of the issues to be debated, but the needs question is just as important. I look forward to ongoing discussions about this matter with honourable senators.

—My question is to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I understand that some charities have said they cannot cope with the demand that Australia's increasing poverty is placing on their resources. Is it a fact that the Government has cut emergency relief funds to the Salvation Army by more than half, or $485,000, while spending over $200,000 advertising the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Salvation Army is one of a large number of non-government organisations that receive grants from our Government under various programs. I shall investigate whether one of those programs has had to be reduced and make that information available to Senator Bjelke-Petersen. There is a program for the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless and funds have been allocated to it. One of the major events occurring in that year is the setting up of a non-government committee chaired by Bishop Hollingworth, with representatives from non-government organisations, and I am sure that the Salvation Army will be represented on it. It is planning a program of events for the International Year of Shelter Week, which will happen shortly, and as well has been consulting with groups throughout the country to see what the needs of the poor for shelter are, and to what extent government programs and programs run through the non-government organisations are meeting them. We have a substantial program of assistance to acknowledge the International Year of Shelter and non-government organisations such as the Salvation Army are certainly involved. When I took over the housing and housing programs part of the Community Services and Health portfolio, one of my first duties-and a very pleasant one it was-was to attend the opening of a new Salvation Army establishment in Melbourne which provides a very high standard of housing, privacy and support for homeless people and those who have problems as well as homelessness. I was pleased to have the opportunity to put on record then our Government's appreciation of the terrific contribution made by the Salvation Army to homeless people and the poor generally.

ANSWER.PARA: I also remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that in our last Budget poor families were the recipients of our new family assistance package which will make available to those families which come within the means test an extra $22 a week per child, rising to $28 a week for children between 13 and 15 years of age, plus an additional $15 a week for those low income families which are renting in the private market. No doubt many of those people are clients, in some sense or another, of the Salvation Army. So, we have a very substantial and varied program of assistance to the poor and we certainly acknowledge and recognise the great contribution to these programs made by organisations such as the Salvation Army. I will have to obtain the specific details of funding from Dr Blewett. Perhaps if Senator Bjelke-Petersen has the correspondence, she will let me have it so that I can give a detailed answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Environment and the Arts aware of Press reports suggesting that Swedish scientists have found that the so-called Antarctic ozone hole has extended northwards to cover Australia? What action is the Government taking to ascertain the veracity of these reports and, further, what action is the Government taking to control chlorofluorocarbons as a result of the recently concluded Montreal protocol?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the media reports which surfaced last Thursday and I am pleased to report to the Senate that advice obtained from Swedish authorities suggests that-not for the first time-the papers got it wrong. In fact, the Swedish Environment Minister, Mrs Dahl, made a statement on this matter which referred only to the ozone hole as it extends to 60 degrees south latitude, and not insofar as it extends to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the bad news is that the initial findings of the study conducted this spring and co-ordinated by the United States of America show that there has been a further depletion of ozone in the Antarctic-in fact, the level is now 15 per cent below the previous lowest level. That further deepening of the hole is a problem for us all. That conclusion is borne out by Australia's own Bureau of Meteorology findings on this matter. As honourable senators would be aware, Australia's monitoring stations, which extend as far south as Macquarie Island, have also been looking at this matter. Australia's ozone levels were slightly lower in September but, fortunately, they recovered during October. We are alive and well here, but the position is still bleak in the Antarctic-and that is not meant to be a pun.

A shorthand description of the protocol is that, as a signatory, Australia will be required to reduce to 1986 levels the production of chlorofluorocarbons by 1989 and then, over a 10-year period by successive reductions, reduce that figure by half. I am being lobbied by some conservation groups that that is not enough and that we should do more. In any event, before becoming a signatory obviously the Government will be in full consultation with the States and other interested parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Given the concern of the Tasmanian Cattlemen's Association, has the Minister received advice that World Heritage listing would affect highland livestock grazing on private land in Tasmania? If so, to what extent would the traditional lifestyles of these people be affected by World Heritage listing?

—I am not specifically aware of a complaint from the Cattlemen's Association in Tasmania. As I have stated repeatedly so far as listing is concerned in north Queensland, where that concern has specifically been raised with me, land use involving the grazing of cattle will continue, and the position would be the same in Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Powell must have been absent from the chamber last week when I answered a question along similar lines. There has been some concern expressed, including in the media, about the change in administration of the EEO programs. What I said in reply to that question last week is that the commitment of the Government to the EEO programs remains as high as ever, although there will be a change in the way in which they are administered. As a result of the reorganisation of the Commonwealth Public Service and some of the efficiency recommendations, departments and agencies will take on a much greater responsibility for EEO programs in terms of recruitment, taking account of special needs of disadvantaged groups which are covered in the legislation, promotion, training and matters of that kind. TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade agree with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, that, given the decision to ban flights by South African Airways, it would be enormously hypocritical of the Federal Government to agree to a joint venture between the Western Australian Government and Anglo-American Pacific of South Africa to treat tailings dumps near Kalgoorlie?

—Not necessarily, Mr President. Commercial arrangements are to be assessed on their merits and in accordance with the extent to which they are consistent with the package of sanctions that have been agreed to by Commonwealth countries meeting at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I am unable to say without taking the question on notice-which I will do-whether or not the particular arrangements that have been the subject of some speculation in Western Australia conform with the agreed package of sanctions. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What are the criteria for legal aid being granted to illegal immigrants? How many illegal immigrants have been granted legal aid? How many illegal immigrants are given legal aid when they arrive at Australian airports with fraudulent documents? How did these migrants know of the availability of legal aid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some notes in the brief from the Attorney-General to this effect: Legal aid in Australia is available through independent State and Territory legal aid commissions, including that of Queensland, the Australian Legal Aid Office in Tasmania and the Northern Territory, and community legal centres in all States and the Australian Capital Territory. It is a basic principle of legal aid that no person should be denied access to the law because of an inability to afford legal representation. In accordance with their charters, legal aid bodies apply criteria which include consideration of the merit of the proceedings and the means of the applicant but do not make distinctions based on nationality or immigration status.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not possible to provide figures as to the number of prohibited non-citizens who have received legal aid. The Attorney-General's Department is currently examining this question by surveying the main legal aid bodies in Australia. All have responded by noting that, although record-keeping is not organised to identify immigration status, it is estimated that the number of illegal immigrants or prohibited non-citizens granted legal aid is extremely small, both in migration and in other matters.

In migration matters, which appear to account for the majority of cases where aid is granted to prohibited non-citizens, the estimate by one legal aid body is that the applicant is a prohibited non-citizen in less than one per cent of cases for which legal aid is approved. Within those few cases, most concern applications for change of status. Indications from other legal aid bodies appear to confirm this view.

Information provided by legal aid bodies suggests that no illegal immigrant or prohibited non-citizen receives legal aid at the time and port of entry into Australia. I am aware, however, that some legal aid bodies provide duty solicitor services to immigration detention centres. Indications from the State and Territory legal aid bodies are that the majority of prohibited non-citizens detained are not aware of the legal aid system in Australia but become aware of it once detained.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE HOUSING IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator MacGibbon asked me a question to do with Tindal Defence Force homes. I have an additional part to my answer. I seek leave for it to be incorporated in Hansard as it is reasonably lengthy.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

(1) The work authorised for Tindal housing was designed to accommodate the harsh local tropical climate which is more extreme than that encountered in coastal regions where the beneficial effects of sea breezes can be utilised to assist natural ventilation.

(2) To ensure an acceptable living environment for the RAAF personnel it was decided that the Defence houses should be equipped with mechanical air conditioning as well as incorporating design features to maximise the benefits of natural ventilation. It is considered that passive design measures alone do not provide sufficient relief for Defence tenants during the oppressive weather of the wet season and other marked seasonal variations in Katherine's climate. Some of the passive features of the Tindal housing designed to achieve better thermal comfort include attention to orientation, higher than standard ceilings, shaded large windows and well insulated construction.

Because the housing is mechanically air conditioned it was decided that the extra 7m2 or so usually provided in non air conditioned Defence houses in the tropics is unnecessary as its purpose is to aid natural ventilation. To further improve the conditions for Defence personnel at Katherine the houses are provided with up to 36m2 of covered outdoor living area.

Some of the earlier prototype houses showed up problems with a ducted whole of house air conditioning system, particularly high operating costs. Later designs were modified to a different system which utilises individually controlled fan coil units in each habitable room, and which provide a lower installation and operating cost.

Before the decision to proceed with the type of house design and full house air conditioning was taken, the cost and residential environmental considerations were carefully evaluated by the then Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Defence.

The design of houses at Tindal for the Defence Force was examined by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. The Committee's Report (Twelfth Report of 1984) on the development of RAAF Base, Tindal, endorsed the works and a motion to proceed with the proposal was passed in the Parliament on 7 June 1984.
