Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to set aside its policy of inaction in the face of economic developments since it brought down the August Budget and to revise its fiscal and wages policies without further delay'.

JOHN STONE
Senator for the State of Queensland
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to set aside its policy of inaction in the face of economic development since it brought down the August Budget and to revise its fiscal and wages policies without further delay.

The momentous events of the past two weeks are fresh in the minds of all honourable senators, even though to listen to the words and observe the attitudes of Government Ministers one could be pardoned for thinking that nothing untoward had occurred. Since Wall Street first fell in the crash on Monday, 19 October, followed by a crash of our own share market on the following day, Tuesday, 20 October, we have heard the echoes reverberate around the world. During the beginning and the middle of last week, the second week of these events, we saw developments in the share markets begin to be translated into developments in the foreign exchange market with very adverse developments beginning to take place against the United States dollar and even more so against the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar fell not merely against strong currencies, such as the Japanese yen and the deutschmark, but even against a very weak currency under those circumstances-the United States dollar.

As I have said, during that time we witnessed some extremely momentous events. At the outset of these events, in fact, on Tuesday, 20 October, Senator Chaney asked a question in this place of Senator Walsh. He suggested, among other things, that the Government ought to consider very seriously postponing the national wage case which was then imminent; it was about to begin the following day. He also suggested that the Government should give very early consider- ation to bringing down a mini-Budget before this Parliament rises for the Christmas recess, having in mind that when it does it will not resume for a further two months which will be, so to speak, two months lost.

Senator Walsh's less than wholly gracious response to Senator Chaney was to describe his two suggestions as palpably stupid. On the very next day Senator Walsh was forced to eat his words, at least in part, when the Government went into the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, through counsel for the Commonwealth, and asked for a postponement of the commencement of the wage case in the light of the events of the previous two days in the world stock markets, including the Australian stock market. That decision by the Government-a volte-face, if you like, at least certainly a volte-face on the view expressed only 24 hours earlier by Senator Walsh-was very much to be welcomed. It showed that at least someone in ministerial ranks was applying some thought to these matters, as distinct from simply lashing out with political and less than wholly worthy responses of the kind given by Senator Walsh on the previous day.

Unfortunately, the Government, having obtained for itself a week's period of grace before the national wage case was brought on again last week, has totally failed to profit from its initially quite wise decision to seek a postponement, which was, of course, granted. In the interim the Government received from its colleagues, one might almost say, in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) a few rather sharp shots across its bows. It received a few threats from Mr Kelty and Mr Simon Crean, the President of the ACTU, and one or two acerbic telephone calls, no doubt, from much less presentable gentlemen than either of those two indicating--

TALK.START.PARA: —And was that Mr Hawke?

—The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was not even here at the time. He was overseas disporting himself in Tipperary and similar places, not to mention the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. As a consequence of those telephone calls and, in one or two cases, quite public remarks by trade union leaders, the Government's knees buckled, as they always do on these occasions, and last week, when the counsel for the Commonwealth came back into the Arbitration Commission, he was duly instructed to propose that the wage case should go ahead and that as from 1 January everyone in this country should receive an increase of $6.50 a week. It was as though nothing had happened in that interim period or, to be more accurate, as though the Government's initial doubts about the wisdom of going ahead had been resolved by what had happened in the intervening week. What had happened in the intervening week was that the share market had fallen even further and the foreign exchange market had started to go into a tailspin as well.

SPEECH.PARA: What a signal to give to the international economic community as to the quality of economic management in this country. There are people who do not have quite the same attachment to the interests of the trade union bosses as our present ministerial ranks and, as I say, who can be pardoned for wondering why, at a moment of national economic crisis, our Government has decided to go into the Arbitration Commission and support a trade union claim for everybody in this country to have his wage or salary raised by $6.50 a week. The Government has made some play with the fact that this will take place, on its proposition, only from 1 January, which is now less than two months away. Some delay!

Let us consider also that other palpably stupid suggestion, according to the Government, which Senator Chaney first raised and which was rebutted in those ungracious terms by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh-namely, the suggestion for an early mini-Budget in order to cut spending and, depending on how big the cuts were, move the Commonwealth Budget into surplus. The Government has not really given any reasons for not following that course other than to say-and I will come to this in a moment-that it does not yet know the full details of the consequences of what has happened in the share markets and the foreign exchange markets. Some people, I have no doubt on the basis of governmental briefing, have suggested that it would not be technically possible for the Government to bring down a mini-Budget before the Parliament rises in December. Yet only on the weekend following the Budget, Senator Walsh, in some appropriately discreet remarks to a gathering in Perth calling itself the Society of Labor Lawyers, claimed that he knew of-I accept that he does-at least 200 separate spending programs in the Commonwealth's own area which had no basis in equity, efficiency, or any other thing. He was most contemptuous of those programs, and quite rightly so. So the suggestion that Senator Walsh and his Department would not have the technical competence to bring forward a mini-Budget between now and the middle of December I find quite unacceptable and I am sure that Senator Walsh does too. The fact of the matter is that that is simply an argument behind which the Government can hide.

The other suggestion that has been made is that we might get it wrong and we might actually do too much at this stage to rein in our budgetary position and to improve the position of our total public sector which, of course, is still borrowing-contrary to some ignorant remarks made during Question Time today by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans-as a proportion of gross domestic product, at a higher rate in total, taking both Federal and State governments together, than our United States counterpart. Of course, he also left aside completely the relative mess in which the two countries find themselves. The United States is certainly in a mess but it is nothing compared with the mess that we are in.

Let us entertain the theoretical possibility of doing too much before Christmas. The only consequences of doing so would be that the Government, under those circumstances, might find itself in the delightful position of being able to let interest rates fall in the new year. I think that prospect would be welcomed by the Government, if ever it were to find itself in that position. But let us not have any of this nonsense about not being able, as yet, to see clearly enough the consequences of these developments in order to be able to act at this stage.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know, I know and senators on the Government side of the chamber certainly know, that the real reason for the Government's stubborn and reckless refusal to begin to move as quickly as possible to restore some degree of confidence in Australian financial markets in these matters is that it does not want to do anything before the New South Wales election. Mr Keating and Mr Hawke who, for these purposes, I think is also classifiable as a member of the New South Wales Right, are bent on protecting their colleague Mr Unsworth. I do not make any comment on that. That is mateship as understood in the Australian Labor Party but, in this case, it is mateship at the expense of the country.

I have already dealt to some degree with the Government's lines. The first is that it is too early to see the detailed consequences of these developments and, therefore, it cannot really be expected to move at this stage. As I have said, I have already dealt with that to some degree and I will come back to it. The Government's second line is: `It's not our fault'. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) of this country was on television last Friday saying-I hope that I am quoting him more or less precisely-`One simply does not know what it will take to get the Americans to do the right thing'. He put his hand on his heart and said, `We simply do not know what it will take to get the Americans to do the right thing'. What a complete abnegation of responsibility on the part of a Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia. Whatever the faults of our American allies may be-I notice the disappearance of the nuclear disarmers-the fact of the matter is that whether they get their policies right or wrong we have to live in the world that they help to create as a consequence. It is no good our crying in our handkerchiefs if, in our opinion, they get it wrong. We have to live in the world that is created. That is the responsibility of the government of the day in this country, the Treasurer of which is the same man who, as I have said, last Friday was bewailing the fact that he simply did not know what it would take to get the Americans to do the right thing.

Let me come to these two lines of argument. As I have said, to some degree I have already dealt with the first argument. The first argument concerns the detailed consequences. Is the Government not satisfied with the detailed consequences, some of which we have already seen? Is it not satisfied with the mess in Rothwells Ltd, the merchant bank in Western Australia-which I do not have time to go into-which reflects no credit on anybody, least of all the Western Australian Government? Is the Government not satisfied with the fact that, at the end of last week, we had the Challenge Bank in Perth, holding a banking licence issued by the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia under the Banking Act, with a run on it? I would be the first to say that I do not believe there is any basis for that run. Any bank which has been issued with a banking licence by the Treasurer and which, therefore, has the Reserve Bank of Australia standing behind it should not have a run occurring on it. Is it not indicative of the lack of confidence in this country, that has now grown up as a consequence of the developments of the past two weeks, that that kind of thing can be happening? Does the Government want any more detailed consequences of that kind before it is prepared to move?

What about the detailed consequences we have seen already in the share markets with the calling off of issue after issue which had previously been planned? Presumably those issues were planned in order to raise capital for the companies concerned, not for those companies to go out and speculate on the stock market-there may be some in that category and I have no time for them if that is the case-but so that most of those companies could try to raise capital in order to be able to do things. Now they have had to pull their share issues off and abort their plans for doing things. Does the Government want any more details of that kind to become evident in addition to those we have already had in the past fortnight?

Above all, of course, what we have seen and what we will see a great deal more of, is the development of greater uncertainty and, through that, we will see an effect on business investment. It is just not good enough for the Government to say that it will sit on its hands and wait for all this to actually appear in the figures to be released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics during the first six months of next year and then it might get around to actually believing it.

As I have said, the Government's second line of defence is: `It's not our fault'. I must say that I am growing rather weary-in fact I have grown weary for some time now-of this line of defence from this Government. When it first came to office we had the $9.6 billion deficit which it inherited from the previous Government as being something which made it impossible for it to do anything about the mess the country was in at the time. That particular line-`It's not our fault'-lasted for about 18 months. The Government's second line of `It's not our fault' concerned the so-called overvalued exchange rate. Mr Acting Deputy President, believe this: that overvalued exchange rate was put in place by a Cabinet which the then Opposition was always assailing for being composed of a lot of farmers. A lot of farmers were deliberately running an overvalued exchange rate! If you believe that you would believe anything.

Of course, in all of that we had no mention or recognition by the Government at any time, until the biennial conference of the Labor Party in Hobart last year, of the consequences of the 1981-82 wage explosion which brought about the absolute shambles, in the metal trades industry particularly, as a consequence and which then moved on in terms of the so-called community standard, as I think the trade union movement then began to call it, throughout the rest of the work force and the rest of the economy. It is true that, at that Hobart conference, the Treasurer actually told the truth about it when he attacked Mr George Campbell of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and accused him of having the corpses of 100,000 dead men around his neck, by which he meant the 100,000 people who became unemployed in the metal trades industry as a consequence of the actions of that same trade union.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an underestimate.
—As Senator Short has accurately reminded me, no doubt it was an underestimate.

SPEECH.PARA: The next pathetic excuse we had from the Government was the adverse movement in the international terms of trade. I have forgotten quite when that one came into vogue; I think it was some time in 1986, if I remember correctly. Then it was all the fault of the international terms of trade. It was not the Government's fault. The Government had never done anything wrong; it was just that the international terms of trade moved against it. We have not heard about the international terms of trade this year because they have actually been improving this year. The Government has not been telling us that, but that has been the case. International terms of trade have been improving since the very beginning of the year.

Now, we have the failure of the policies of the United States of America as the thing really responsible for the mess we in Australia are in today. Of course, that is ludicrous. That may be what is responsible for the mess that the United States is in today. But the mess we are in today is due to the failures on the part of this Government over the last three years or so. It is high time we got away from this romanticising and myth making on the part of the Government and got back to the real world. The real world is one in which the Government persists in fiddling while our economy falls down, and indeed while the international economy begins to fall down also.

In response to a number of questions the week before last, Senator Walsh said there were two critical tests to which he would have regard in deciding whether we would need to take action in this country. The first was the extent to which those developments depressed Australia's income from exports. The second was the extent to which they might provide a massive withdrawal of capital. As to the first, as I have said before, in the past six months or so we have had growing ebullience in the commodity markets of the world; they have been rising. The major reason for that has been that there have been fears of inflation moving into those markets during that time. That is what has been largely responsible for pushing those commodity markets up, as some speculative elements have begun to enter them. Of course, Australia was benefiting from that, not only from the fact that the prices for our products were rising but also because under those circumstances the Australian dollar came to be seen as a so-called commodity currency; it became attractive. For a while it became almost the flavour of the month.

It follows from that that, in the light of the events of the last two weeks, which have produced an outlook for deflation, not inflation, in those commodity markets, we can now look forward to and have already begun to see a situation in which the Australian dollar is still regarded as a commodity currency in a world in which the commodity currency is no longer the flavour of the month but is a competitor for the ash can. I am afraid that that may very well be the case.

My final point relates to Senate Walsh's view about capital flows. Contrary to his view, we do not need a massive withdrawal of capital to signal the storm signs. All we need is to have capital inflow from abroad dry up, which is what we certainly had. Last week in any case we did see a massive withdrawal of capital. I asked a question of Senator Walsh on that matter last Friday. It is true that the Minister did not seem to understand at that time that, if the Reserve Bank of Australia was buying, as it certainly was, massive amounts of Australian dollars-amounts of $2 billion were even mentioned-somebody must be selling them to it. The only people who could have been were those withdrawing capital from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard another rant from Senator Stone about the need for everybody to wear a hair shirt. How many of the listeners to this debate or of the people in the public gallery can believe that that rant has come from a man who is double dipping, drawing a $34,000 a year Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension as well as his parliamentary salary and whatever other income he may earn from being a columnist or whatever else he may do which is not publicly known. Of course, that is typical of the humbug and hypocrisy of the side of politics which Senator Stone represents. When, during the election campaign, it was put to him by Paul Malone, a Canberra Times journalist, that his having retired at 55 as Secretary to the Treasury after, I think, a full 30 years of service and therefore drawing a superannuation pension of around $33,000 or $34,000 a year financed by the employer-whatever contributions he may have made would be in addition to that-might cause him a bit of a problem when he became a senator, and that incidentally he had the regulations changed at the time that he retired in order to entitle him to that $33,000 or $34,000 a year, Mr Stone defended his receipt of the benefit and said that it was not a matter of public interest. I can understand why he did not want it to be a matter of public interest, particularly when he plugs the line that he normally does. But it is a matter of public interest. In his article Paul Malone said this of Mr Stone:

SPEECH.PARA: He said the benefit was derived from 30 years of service to the Commonwealth. He rejected the suggestion that the benefit was for people who retired, saying they were a condition of employment.

To turn those words around a little bit but to express exactly the same position, the very unionists whom Senator Stone spends half his life condemning say, `We will not surrender hard won working conditions'. That is the common response from people in the industrial labour movement whom Senator Stone is forever condemning for adopting that attitude and therefore refusing to co-operate or not readily co-operating in the sorts of adjustments that need to be made because of changing economic circumstances.

So there is one rule for Senator Stone, who will not surrender any of his hard won conditions of employment as a public servant for 30 years. But there is a totally different rule for people in the industrial labour movement, most of whom incidentally have incomes significantly lower than either Senator Stone's Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension or his senatorial salary. Not only do those people not have a double dip; the first dip is not as big as either of Senator Stone's. He has the effrontery to come in here with this motion and the sort of rhetoric that he has used in support of it today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shooting the messenger.

—Senator Chaney says that I am trying to shoot the messenger. Well, Senator Chaney has also adopted the double standard. Other people, particularly those associated with the industrial labour movement, have to surrender what they call their hard won conditions of employment, but Senator Stone does not. Incidentally, Senator Stone mentioned the cutting of 200 programs, which is something to which I had referred and which is two Budgets out of date, as he knows very well. Indeed, since I first made that reference, we have taken $5 1/2 billion worth of expenditure cutting decisions. But some of the 200 programs that I had in mind are still left. Senator Stone's double dip is one of them. I do not know whether he wants us to do something about that.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the more unedifying spectacles on the tory side of politics in recent times has been the trio of Stone, Howard and Fraser-the three points of a triangle-each blasting away at the other two in an endeavour to lay off the blame for having wrecked the Australian economy in the late 1970s and early 1980s. I must say that I almost fell off this bench when Senator Stone started to complain about the wages explosion of 1981-82. Who on earth does Senator Stone think was responsible for that if it was not the tory government of the day, advised as it was by him as Treasury Secretary that wages policies do not work and that it is best to let that issue work itself out in the market-place? The Fraser Government tried that. In May 1981 the Fraser Government formally abdicated any responsibility for a national wages policy and said, `Let the market-place work it out', acting on advice from Senator Stone. What happened? (Quorum formed) I was just saying that I heard Senator Stone condemning the situation which led to the wages explosions of 1981 and 1982. What caused those was the official abdication of responsibility, in May 1981, by the then Government, when it said, `We accept no responsibility for a national wages policy. We believe it should be worked out in the market-place'. Acting on the advice that Senator Stone had given the then Government, it was worked out in the market-place. What we got was a 13 per cent wage hike in 1981 and a 14 per cent wage hike in 1982, which, as Senator Stone has correctly, for once, said, was a major factor in the very high level of unemployment of 10.5 per cent in early 1983, and, of course, the 11.5 per cent inflation rate which this Government also inherited.

I found a curious ambivalence about Senator Stone's speech today. On the one hand he seemed to be attracted to something that appeals to many case hardened tories. They like to have one day's or one year's experience repeated ad nauseam. They love reliving the past and never having anything changed. Half the time it seemed as if we were having a re-run of last week's speech from Senator Stone. I thought about incorporating my answer to it in the Hansard, to let us get on with the business of the Senate instead of wasting any more time on this silly urgency motion. On the other hand there was another half to Senator Stone's speech, which, however, was completely in conflict with the motion that he moved last week. The motion that he moved last week said that the Commonwealth Government has to get stuck into its own spending programs instead of passing the kick back down to the States through cutting State spending programs. But today Senator Stone took to task Senator Evans for failing to mention, in answer to a question, that although the Commonwealth Budget was in balance, the States were borrowing from the Australian capital market the equivalent of 3.3 per cent of gross domestic product. So on the one hand he said last week-as we would expect any truckler of Bjelke-Petersen's to say-that the Commonwealth Government should not be giving the States any economic shocks as a consequence of the circumstances we find ourselves in; it should confine all its adjustments to the Commonwealth's own purpose expenditures. On the other hand today he is implicitly saying to Senator Evans, and I suppose all the rest of us, that we ought to do something to jerk the States into line. He said last week that we should leave the States alone, and he says this week that we should jerk them into line.

The Opposition is very gung ho on cutting government expenditure as long as it remains an abstract proposition and does not get down to any specific details. In contrast to Senator Stone's speech and the normal attitude of the Opposition, we have, as somebody else observed during Question Time, Senator MacGibbon wanting to spend another $100,000 on a junket for a couple of politicians to go off to the United Nations for three months. He is highly critical of the Government for cutting that out. The Opposition wants to pay pensions to millionaires, and, of course, it wants to go on double dipping. Those of them who are double dipping, such as Senator Stone, insist that they go on double dipping while simultaneously arguing that people whose first and only dip is less than either of their double dips should make the sacrifices and the adjustments.

On the question of government expenditure, I am still waiting for the list of expenditure cutting programs which Mr Howard promised the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on Tuesday of last week, and for a copy of which I formally asked him later that day, because I would be very interested to look at Mr Howard's list of spending cuts. He promised it to the ABC, but he obviously has not delivered it. We can assume from that only that he has welshed on the promise and he will not be providing it to the ABC or to me. But this draws attention to the double standards which the whole Opposition practises. We have not just Senator Stone's double standards, the double dip double standard, but the whole Opposition practice of the double standard of demanding in the abstract that expenditure be reduced, but when it comes down to the detail and the nitty-gritty actually argueing for increases in expenditure in various areas, all the way from the $40,000 that it wasted on a silly motion to suspend Standing Orders-incidentally, about $40,000 an hour, is what it costs to run the Senate, so about $40,000 went up the spout-and Senator MacGibbon would have us spend another $100,000 providing a junket for a couple of politicians in the form of a trip to the United Nations. Then we get down to the really big spending items, such as paying pensions to millionaires, which would cost at least another $300m, and to the building of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, which would cost another $600m, and so on.

Lest somebody says that the Opposition would save money in health expenditure, I want to blow that furphy out of the water again. The plain fact is that total health expenditure in Australia equals just under 7.5 per cent of gross domestic product. That figure has fallen in recent years-not gone up, as many people would have us believe. It is just under 7.5 per cent, and the present trend is that it is declining. In the United Kingdom it is just under 7 per cent, in Canada it is just over 8 per cent, and in the United States, which has the sort of health delivery system which the Opposition would inflict on Australia, if it had the opportunity, it is 11 per cent. To convert that into Australian dollars, on the size of the Australian economy and so on, that would mean extra spending on health of about $10 billion for a health outcome which is certainly no better, and arguably is inferior. There is no great mystery about why that has happened, because the United States health system combines the worst features of all systems. It allows for insurance and for medical services to be marketed to insured patients in a manner similar to the marketing of Coca-Cola or breakfast foods. Under those circumstances, where the supplier of the service is drumming up business and the user, so-called, of the service-although the use is normally instigated by the supplier-pays almost nothing directly but pays only an insurance premium, it is wholly predictable that there will be a cost explosion for no particularly good outcome. Yet that is precisely what the Opposition would inflict on Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have been sitting here listening with great patience to the Minister. I am not aware that the motion before the chamber has the slightest reference to our health system, nor am I aware that my own remarks made any reference to that matter which would justify this totally irrelevant tirade by the Minister about the health system. I wonder whether he would not mind, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, addressing himself, just for the last four minutes of his remarks, to the motion before the chamber and saying something about the economy and what the Government proposes to do about it, if anything.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone, on the other hand, when it comes to his $34,000 a year Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension in addition to his parliamentary salary and whatever else he earns from the private sector through writing newspaper articles or whatever, refuses to acknowledge that there is anything untoward at all in his continuing to receive his $34,000 a year Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension and a parliamentary salary as well-a double dip from the public purse. SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Walsh referred in an aside to the fact that I also write a newspaper column. That is perfectly true. I do, and I get paid for it. TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to table it all?

SPEECH.PARA: As far as wider adjustments to wages and fiscal policy are concerned, that would surely, I would have thought, depend on what happens to our trade prospects and to international capital movements following the share market collapse. In that article, which was headed `Sit tight and assess things as they unfold', Professor John Nevile made the point that in his view:

the Government is right in not doing anything dramatic. We don't want to make the problem appear more dramatic and more important than it is, and in any case the options for doing very much are not great.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the uncertain outlook and the danger of unnecessarily stifling domestic economic activity, a pre-Christmas mini-Budget is a dreadful prospect.

If anything the Government should be contemplating an expansionary fiscal policy with some stimulation coming from moderate wage increases of which I intend to say a little more later.

What have been the economic developments since the Budget, which this matter of urgency refers to as an August Budget but which was brought down in September? They are none other than what has been known as a share market meltdown that started on Wall Street two weeks ago and subsequently cut something like 40 per cent off the value of Australian shares. This returns them to levels that prevailed a year or so ago and, incidentally, to levels where the yields are much more realistic than they have been for the last 12 months or so. As I mentioned earlier, since that occurred we have witnessed one Australian merchant bank being saved-if I can use that word-for the time being by the combined action of the Western Australian Labor Government and certain Australian millionaires. On Friday the Reserve Bank of Australia, quite properly, provided funds for the Challenge Bank when its reserves were challenged by depositors withdrawing funds following rumours that the bank was in trouble. In these instances action was taken by governments or government instrumentalities and I am surprised that the Opposition parties support these regulatory and interventionist activities and seem to be calling for more, given their previous ideological stance on this issue. Governments have already acted and, as I have said, the Western Australian Government supported that financial institution and the Reserve Bank, quite properly, supported the Challenge Bank with the liquidity it needed.

We do not know yet which Australian financial institutions, stockbrokers and public companies will be adversely affected by the stock market plunge. It is a matter of waiting to see and responding, as most of the economists I have just quoted indicated, to circumstances as they arise. Therefore, it is a matter of responding to individual cases unless a general collapse of our financial markets appears to be imminent. As yet there are no grounds for believing that as most of the people interviewed for that Australian Financial Review article indicated. Professor Hogan noted elsewhere in that article that most of the dumping, it would seem, was due to foreign investors selling their Australian shares as a general panic measure. As I said last week in a debate similar to this debate, the situation was made worse by the fact that the Hong Kong Stock Exchange was closed down.

We all know that foreign investment, by its very nature, is a fair weather phenomenon. Those who have wooed foreign investment in the past should realise by now that in the past depressions and severe recessions we have experienced on a world scale, foreigners tend to withdraw their investment as they seek security closer to home or, as do some domestic investors, to offset other problems they have. It is, so to speak, the downside of an investment boom that when things go bad investment is withdrawn. It happened in the late 1880s, again in the 1930s and we have seen something similar happening in the last couple of weeks. Those treasurers and advisers who made the Australian economy dependent on foreign investment may yet witness the phenomenon again. I repeat the call I have been making ever since 1981 that Australian governments must act to restrict or to regulate severely foreign investment in this country if they do not want to see our economy severely undermined by panic stricken foreign investors.

Senator Stone's matter of urgency calls for the Government to revise its fiscal and wages policies without further delay. We have already had a series of contractionary financial measures cutting expenditure since the 1986-87 Budget. For example, the Government has postponed the normal consumer price indexation increase of pensions; it has imposed tertiary fees and taxed items such as fruit juice and milk; it has reduced social security payments to the young unemployed and has caused additional problems in the farming area by the assets testing of unemployed benefit recipients. All of this has been done in the name of fiscal responsibility to achieve a balanced Budget to please foreign financiers and the New Right. The same working Australians whose real wages have fallen since 1983 have been forced to bear the brunt of fiscal restraint already instituted by this Government.

The tax cuts delivered by the Keating tax reform package were also of greatest benefit to those who were the most well off-the highest income earners. Average and below average income earners, and certainly social security recipients, have done rather badly under the Labor Government as it sets out to woo its big business friends both here and overseas. Yet this Government is proposing to further lower business taxes despite the fact that, as I said in debate last week, our corporate taxes are the lowest in real terms of those of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries except Turkey. The contribution made by company tax to revenue has fallen steadily from 17 per cent 15 years ago to less than 10 per cent now and the effective rate of tax paid by many of our top companies is less than 15c in the dollar. Again as I said last week, it is the principals of many of those companies who are bleating about the fact that they need further assistance from governments. In addition, we need to tax that part of the profits made by superannuation funds which comes from investment overseas. The revenue gained from that must be used to increase social security payments, particularly payments to the elderly and families, and to reduce taxes for the poorest, rather than the richest, Australians.

Since something like 2 1/2 million Australians live in poverty, wage restraint and fiscal restraint, of the sort advocated by the Opposition, would again be at their expense. It sits ill, I might add, with the action by Mr Alan Bond to offer millions of dollars to his senior executives to remain with his companies. It seems to me that of all the suggestions made by the Opposition and business leaders, this one relating to wage restraint--

These reports bring forward the opportunity once again to say a few words about medical research in Australia. Medical research is one of the jewels in the crown of Australian science achievement and a cause of considerable pride to this nation. A considerable contribution is made by Australian doctors and scientists to the world in general. The reports for 1984 and for 1985 are slightly different in some respects. The 1985 report complains about the cuts in medical research funding. The report indicates that the funding of $45.712m made available to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) for the support of medical research in 1985 represents a standstill in real terms. Fortunately, the 1986 report is able to show that funding in the 1985-86 Budget to medical research was significantly increased, resulting in an increase of 22 per cent-or 11 per cent in real terms-to $55.850m. If one looks at the Budget Statement in the current year, one sees that medical research grants will rise to $64.4m in 1987-88, an increase of 9.4 per cent.

The 1985 report indicates the important step taken by the Council in establishing an Animal Experimentation Ethics Committee to ensure a minimum degree of public disquiet about the use of animals in experiments-something that continues to be necessary, but which has to be controlled and monitored in a humane and sensible fashion. I have great faith in the NHMRC being able to do that. As Senator Peter Baume said last Thursday, the NHMRC is a body which commands a wide degree of respect and trust in the community.

The 1986 report draws attention to the Council's Medical Research Ethics Committee being involved in activities related to in vitro fertilisation (IVF) centres in Australia and the production of a report by the NHMRC entitled In-Vitro Fertilisation Centres in Australia. Their observance of National Health and Medical Research Council Guidelines. The report stated that no centre had allowed cloning experiments or surrogacy arrangements, and that no research had been undertaken which would normally allow an embryo to develop in vitro beyond the stage at which implantation would normally occur. It records by and large the extremely important work carried out by these IVF centres around Australia and their comprehensive adherence to the guidelines laid down by the Council.

I believe that Australia has a quite outstanding record in medical research. For example, in combating acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) the work that has been done by Professor Penny, the work previously done by Professor Penington, and the work that is being done by Professor Dwyer in Sydney are at the forefront of research. I pay great tribute to the Government on this occasion which has been generous in providing funds for AIDS research and in providing funds for medical research in Australia. It is one of the areas in which Australia makes an outstanding contribution. It is an area in which the interest shown by both sides of Parliament in providing adequate funds needs to be recognised. I congratulate the NHMRC on its 1985 and 1986 reports and I look forward to a 1987 report which indicates the continuing progress in a number of fields that are of vital concern to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual reports of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) of 1985 and 1986 both make reference to the work of the Medical Research Ethics Committee. From the 1985 report at page 73, it is clear that the Ethics Committee has started to examine the adequacy of institutional arrangements. On pages 8 and 9 of the 1986 report are set out some of the activities of the Medical Research Ethics Committee during 1986. These include the establishment of guidelines for in vitro fertilisation (IVF) and related research.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a considerable amount of noise, heat and emotion generated over these difficult questions of bioethics. They have been raised in the Senate recently and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) has been asked to clarify some of the positions relating to committees to oversee bioethics research.

The NHMRC plays a pivotal role in ensuring that Australian research workers-particularly in the area of bioethical research related to IVF-display adequate ethical standards. We face very real difficulties today and we will face greater difficulties in the years to come. On the one hand, we have the world of science, which is concerned with the capacity of people to carry out and develop techniques. On the other hand, we have the world of philosophy-particularly the world of moral philosophy-which is concerned with trying to identify the proper ways in which we should behave. Particularly in IVF and related research, the two areas overlap and intersect. The difficulty is that we have a clash between one world which uses one language and one set of values and another world which uses another language and another set of values. I happen to believe that it is quite possible to resolve the difficult ethical issues in these bioethical areas, in the areas of IVF and related research. I believe that the NHMRC is the best vehicle we have available in Australia. It is proceeding to examine these matters and it will give us the right answers. It will involve some brokerage between ministers of religion, who have one particular view, and scientists, at the other extreme, who may have a different point of view, and also between citizens, who want to see the benefits of IVF available to them but who want to avoid the excesses which have occurred at different times in history.

I make a plea, particularly in view of some of the discussions we have had in the Senate in the past week or so, that any discussion be calm, considered, moderate and conciliatory. While the Parliament awaits a response from the Government on the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, I remind the Senate that a committee consisting of five or six senators does not, of itself, represent the Senate and the Senate Committee work on this question of IVF-important as it is-is only one of the inputs which this Government will be receiving on this important matter. The NHMRC will be another important input. I stress that there are functions of the Executive Government which belong to the Executive Government alone. One of those is to make decisions of the kind that are before it now. I have never heard a proposition that the Government is obliged to accept the findings of a Senate committee. Such findings should constitute one of the inputs. I hope that on these matters, which were dealt with in the NHMRC report, the Government will not allow its proper role to be pre-empted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to congratulate the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) on its 1985 and 1986 reports which are before us today. I have had a small involvement with the NHMRC through the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, as many research projects depend on the use of animals. Today the criteria are much higher than they have ever been. This year a complete revision of the guidelines is to be undertaken, which I commend. The work of the Senate Committee has been extensive with examination in areas such as experiments using native mammals, experiments on pain and stress-which is something which has to be looked at very carefully-and strategies for minimising the number of animals used.
