DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY BILL 1987COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill 1987 and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Bill 1987-which is the machinery Bill whereby effect can be given to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill-are being debated cognately. I hope to deal with both fairly briefly. The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. As honourable senators would be aware, these Bills have the function of replacing the legislation which was put on the statute books only 12 months ago by the Government to provide for a Commonwealth guarantee charge. That legislation provided for the imposition of a charge on those Commonwealth authorities seeking a Commonwealth guarantee on borrowings that they might make in the capital markets. It has been found-I think in effect it was possibly predictable, although it is easy to be wise after the event, as we all know-that the original legislation simply did not work very well, if I may use mild language.

SPEECH.PARA: Although these Bills aim, and their predecessors aimed, at an objective with which I think we on this side of the chamber entirely agree, their predecessors did not very effectively attain that objective. In other words, in the last 12 months, the Government has discovered that authorities which were government-owned actually had an implicit guarantee on any borrowings they made by virtue of their government ownership. Thus even those authorities which did not actually seek from the Government an explicit guarantee on their borrowings and, therefore, paid no guarantee charge last year, nevertheless found that the markets treated their borrowings, to all intents and purposes, as being implicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth. I do not want to imply that the markets put precisely the same capital market rating upon paper issued by those authorities, which were only implicitly guaranteed, as it put on the borrowings of equivalent authorities which were explicitly guaranteed. But I think experience has shown that the difference between the two was really very small and certainly not of a magnitude to justify, as a commercial decision, the application by those authorities for an explicit guarantee. As events have turned out, it would have been an unwise commercial decision for them to do so and that is why that original legislation has been rendered ineffective by the judgment of the markets.

As I have said, we now have this legislation to replace that earlier failed legislation. I repeat that those earlier Bills aimed at, and these Bills aim at, an objective with which I and the Opposition generally entirely agree. Perhaps it is best expressed in the statement of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) in her second reading speech in these terms:
. . . to ensure that the effective cost of borrowings to authorities-
that is to say, the Government authorities-
was more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers . . .

Or borrowers of an equivalent stature. To the extent that that objective sought to put governmentally-owned authorities on to a level footing with competitors certainly in the capital markets, it is an entirely desirable objective and remains an entirely desirable objective, and we agree with it fully. As a consequence, we will support this legislation.

Of course, these authorities will become subject to the proposed new levy only when they actually undertake borrowings. I suppose that one of our problems in this country for some time now-it is certainly no less today-is that a very large volume of public sector borrowings are still going on. During the course of Question Time today Senator Gareth Evans responded to a question and implied that the present Commonwealth Government could congratulate itself-this is a practice in which Senator Evans is proficient-for the fact that the Commonwealth Budget deficit is now smaller, as a proportion of gross domestic product, than the United States of America Federal Budget deficit. I am prepared to accept that it was inadvertence on the part of Senator Evans, because I understand him to be rather ignorant of these matters, that his comparison failed to refer to the fact that the key element is not the Federal Budget deficit but the total public sector borrowing requirement over all levels of government, whether in the United States or here. In Australia, the State governments and their instrumentalities are very large borrowers. Therefore, notwithstanding the relatively small deficit in the Commonwealth's own Budget, leaving aside the fancy accounting which produces that to some degree, the total public sector borrowing requirement in Australia is still appreciably higher than the total public sector borrowing requirement in the United States. I make those remarks in passing in order to draw out the point that this total public sector borrowing requirement is the one on which our attention should be focused.

Of course, in the present circumstances and without going over ground already covered in the urgency motion in the chamber this afternoon, given the very poor performance of most of the State governments-I think Queensland is a notable exception-in bringing down their Budgets recently, we still have a level of total public sector borrowing requirements in this country in 1987-88 which is far too high. In those circumstances, whatever one may think of the present state of the Commonwealth's Budget deficit, it still remains the case that the Commonwealth has a public duty, in terms of its responsibilities for macroeconomic management of this country, to move its Budget into surplus in order to offset the dereliction of duty on the part of State governments, not least the New South Wales Government which, as I observed in a different context, I think last week, has been awarded the order of the lemon, so far as State budgeting is concerned, by the States Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs in Perth. This was awarded a week or two ago after the Institute had surveyed all the State Budgets.

The total public sector borrowing requirement is the deficit of the Commonwealth and the deficits of all the States, the borrowing requirements of the State authorities and the borrowing requirements of Commonwealth authorities. It is the borrowings by Commonwealth authorities which are the subject of the Bills before us this afternoon. Which are those authorities? Of course, they cover a quite diverse range of instrumentalities, but the major ones within the Commonwealth's field of operation are authorities such as Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation, however, is not covered by this piece of legislation because it is a financial intermediary and as such is seen in the financial markets as a financial intermediary rather than a Commonwealth authority. As I have said, the legislation covers Australian Airlines and other bodies such as the Australian National Railways Commission.

Of course, those bodies may very well need to undertake borrowings from time to time. Indeed, that is one of the great problems that the two instrumentalities that I referred to-Qantas and Australian Airlines-have. They will both have to spend very considerable amounts of money on capital re-equipment programs and therefore they will almost certainly have to be in the capital markets to raise such capital. Of course, this is one of the reasons we have had a certain amount of scurrying around on the Government's part recently to terminate the two-airline agreement in order to put even greater pressure on Australian Airlines so that in turn the Government's proposals, as yet undeclared, for the privatisation of Australian Airlines will take on a more persuasive coloration. There will be a very similar effect upon Qantas which, if anything, has even larger capital requirements than Australian Airlines is likely to have.

Those remarks having been made, I think I need do no more than say that the Opposition will not oppose these Bills but draws the attention of the Senate to the fact that, had a little more thought been applied to the question at issue before the Bills which preceded these were brought into this chamber a year ago, we would not be spending further time on this matter today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill 1987 and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Bill 1987 which, as Senator Stone has already said, is a substitute for the Commonwealth Guarantees (Charges) Act of 1987. Basically, the concept is to allow a levy on all borrowings by semi-government authorities at a rate not exceeding 0.5 per cent. In the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives, it was notable that a great deal of time was taken up in discussion of the notion of privatisation. These very government and semi-government authorities will be the subject of the privatisation debate as it continues through this year, presumably getting a bit of a hiccup on the graph when the Australian Labor Party Conference takes place, and finally coming to some type of fitful conclusion, presumably next year, when we may see some legislation arising out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to concentrate on the issue of the semi-government authorities' borrowings and look at it from the point of view of whether the country benefits from the existence of those semi-government authorities or whether the privatisation debate has substance. Unfortunately, the debate consists of a number of myths, many of which have not been clarified and many of which are simply assertions that something is good and something else is bad. The Government obviously, in terms of its new-found fervour for privatisation, as expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is looking at the money coming in as a result of selling off public assets. These sales will then assist the Government in next year's Budget to announce a budgetary surplus.

The Government has embraced the view that a Budget surplus is a good thing because it pleases the domestic and foreign businessmen and bankers. But, unfortunately, selling off public enterprises will give the Government a once only flow of revenue, in the year that that revenue is received. It is important to realise that this is a once only injection of revenue. The same public enterprises cannot be sold every year. Therefore, the sale will create further reductions in subsequent Budget revenues, for the very real reason that there will be no future revenue from those public enterprises which make profits and remit some of those profits to Consolidated Revenue.

Furthermore, insofar as buyers of the public enterprises borrow heavily in Australia and overseas to finance their purchases, the Government's overall revenue from company tax will fall in future years. Of course, the Government could stop this revenue loss by abolishing or limiting the extent to which negative gearing can be used to reduce artificially or negate the profits of companies which previously paid tax. However, that would require a form of regulation, a way of controlling companies so that they act in the public interest. The Hawke-Keating Government has shown that it is trying to persuade businessmen and bankers of the very opposite, that is, that the Hawke Labor Government is wholeheartedly in favour of deregulation. It seems unlikely that the Government could go down that track to try to stem the loss to revenue.

The Government argues that by selling off public enterprises it will reduce the Commonwealth Government's borrowing requirements, thereby making room for private borrowings. I suppose the Hawke Government is in good company because it has joined the Opposition, Milton Friedman and a variety of other people in believing that private sector borrowings are automatically good while public sector borrowings are automatically bad. Even if we leave aside the loss to revenue brought about by private borrowers who negatively gear-something on which the Government has also had a reversal of position and has now re-extended negative gearing within the economy-I cannot see what is intrinsically good or worth while about a private company borrowing to buy, for instance, Australian Airlines. Why is the welfare of Australian citizens automatically increased if the Government stops borrowing to buy new planes for Australian Airlines and at the same time a private company starts borrowing to do the same? The Government and the Opposition have made this point that they wish to argue. The only evidence that they have that it is desirable to reduce the public sector borrowing requirement is that the bankers like it-presumably some of those sage and wise bankers who lent over $100 billion of their depositors' money to Latin American countries which have little, if any, intention of paying it back.

It seems as though the Government's ideological loathing of governments borrowings will be used as part of the excuse for selling off a variety of public enterprises, and the Government will probably go about it in the following manner. It will start winding back its borrowing requirements and also winding back the allowable borrowing for semi-government authorities. This, of course, will prevent public enterprises from updating their capital equipment. As that becomes outdated, the quality of services provided by those semi-government authorities will be reduced. I use the case of Australian Airlines as an example. This would mean that it would be flying old planes and providing a service so obviously inferior to that provided by Ansett Airlines of Australia that we would have a self-fulfilling prophecy. It would then be easy for the Government to point to Australian Airlines and to say that it should be sold off.

Quite frankly, if a private entrepreneur let one of his companies run down, so that he could sell it cheaply to his mates, the shareholders would have grounds for claiming that they had been deceived. Why then is this Government interested in saying and probably doing something very similar with regard to public enterprises, by starving them of capital which they need as a prelude, from the Government's point of view, to selling them off? The Government, and here I should probably say its senior Ministers, argues that privatised public enterprises will be able to offer better services to consumers. That is another of the myths. The assumption that the private sector can provide better services than the public sector, especially when a public sector monopoly is replaced by a private sector monopoly, can clearly be brought into question by looking at the example of the privatisation of British Telecom. There is now widespread agreement in Britain, substantiated by the Office of Telecommunications, the watchdog set up by the Thatcher Government when British Telecom was privatised, that there has been a marked deterioration of British Telecom's services since privatisation. For instance, the pay phone system has deteriorated since last year, from one in five boxes out of order, to one in four boxes out of order. Shareholders might be better off because British Telecom's profits have increased since privatisation, but its delivery of services to the public has suffered. Some commentators believe that British Telecom's increased efficiency, as marked by increased profits, and its increased inefficiency, as measured by delivering services to telephone users, are both the result of staff reductions. That would make sense, and I think that is why many Australians, who work hard for the Government's public enterprises, fear that this Government's sudden commitment to privatisation at the senior levels of the Cabinet will in fact be carried into fruition.

There are a number of substantive reasons why public enterprises should not be sold off. First of all there is the problem of who will buy them-a point which I do not think is lost on too many Australians as a result of the share market situation of the last few weeks. The proponents of privatisation assert that there will now be thousands of shareholders who will own a few shares in Telecom Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines or the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. I am not at all sure that substituting a few thousand shareholders for every person in Australia owning them is an advance, but some people see it that way. The reality is that the effective control of these companies will not pass into the hands of those shareholders in the same way as the effective control of most major companies in Australia is not in the hands of small shareholders. In fact they are controlled by large corporate shareholders who make the final decisions. The people who direct those companies are effectively the owners, rather than the owners in a legal sense-the shareholders. So large Australian multinationals and foreign multinationals will in fact become the effective controllers of those organisations and not the Government.

In any debate about privatisation one probably looks at the airlines as the first cab off the rank example. Here I ask: Will Ansett Airlines simply swallow up Qantas and Australian Airlines either immediately or in the future? How would a government, which is so passionately committed to deregulating everything, prevent that from occurring at a later stage, or would a future government want to continue a commitment to preventing it from happening? On what basis would the Government prevent it from happening, if it was happy for our media to be bought up, as it was, by a few wealthy investors? Why then should it stand in the way of our airlines being bought up similarly by a few wealthy investors? One would also want to ask in those circumstances whether the Government would be happy to see Qantas, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank or Telecom owned by foreign companies. If not, how would it propose to stop those public enterprises being controlled by Japanese or American companies? As an example, I again use the airlines. What if Qantas were owned by Japan Airlines Ltd or the Commonwealth Bank were owned by the Bank of America? A lot of people say that the Government would move to prevent that, but I am not at all sure that the Treasurer would have anything against it. If he did want to prevent it, I am not sure what he would be able to do about it in his much endeared deregulated financial environment.

There is also the problem of subsidisation, whereby we would probably end up with more tax and certainly less equity in the Australian community. The availability and cost of certain services-airline services, telephone services and schools in rural Australia-are influenced by government policy which, in effect, subsidies services to those areas through, for example, servicing the more popular airline routes, or in the provision of telephones by the more used system. Where will we be able to get the money to provide those types of services? Obviously it will come from direct taxation and not from the cross-subsidisation which currently occurs.

In those circumstances, what would happen to the cost and the availability of these services, if the respective public enterprises were privatised? I think that the Government would find it very difficult to subsidise those at anywhere near the level at which they are being subsidised at the moment. If the Government does not do that, what form of regulation can we possibly imagine would compel a company to provide telephone services to the people of, for example, Eulo in my State? The cost of those is astronomical compared with the cost of putting a new telephone in a house in a Brisbane suburb. It is fairly obvious that a private company would not have a bar of it unless it were compelled to ignore the profit motive and to address the public interest. I am not quite sure what type of hybrid operation we would then have, with a private company being directed by the Government to ignore the profit motive and to address the public interest.

Surely, under those circumstances it makes a lot more sense for the Government to stay in the area because it is the Government's obligation to address that public interest. It is not a private firm's obligation to do so. If the Government continues such subsidies, of course we will all end up paying more taxes to pay for them, and the loss in government revenue from the profits in the public areas-for example, the profitable parts of Telecom, Australia Post and Australian Airlines, amongst others-will be lost. Therefore the total jump in taxation that would be necessary, would be much higher than if the Government retained these profit making areas of the public sector. The fact that those who end up owning the public enterprises pay less tax while other Australians pay more tax surely at the end of the day simply exacerbates the inequalities that would occur under those circumstances.

At this stage the discussion has only taken the form of headlines, statements made on the stairs coming into this place and various propositions made at speaking engagements of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. They have singled out as an example the same one that I have singled out, that is, the airlines. They have raised the issue of Qantas and Australian Airlines. Of course, the Prime Minister has already been gloating to New York bankers about the impending Government budgetary surplus, which, as I have said before, will reflect the sale of these public enterprises.

This Government, of course, is committed to deregulation, Budget surpluses and reduced government borrowings. Privatisation is only a means to that particular end. At the moment the Government talks as if it has no plans for privatising the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Telecom or the education system. Those honourable senators who are inclined to believe what the Government says should remember what Mr Hawke said about privatisation on 29 August 1985. On that particular occasion he was attacking the then Leader of the Opposition, Andrew Peacock, because he had reaffirmed the commitment of the Liberal Party of Australia to privatisation. I must say that the Liberal Party at least in that respect has been consistent. Andrew Peacock at that time was making this reaffirmation with regard to statements that had been made by Steele Hall and the late Alan Missen expressing doubts about Howard's privatisation plans. In an article in the Herald, Prime Minister Hawke summed up, I think eloquently, the case against privatisation when he said:
Privatisation will see profitable areas of government activity transferred to wealthy private shareholders. Taxpayers will be left subsidising the loss-making activities of the Government.

Privatisation will not lead to lower taxation. In the main, government corporations are financed by selling their services. Privatisation, by contrast, would probably see a lift in taxes as the Government would be forced into subsidising uneconomic services. It is especially shortsighted to give up future dividends and interest flows in return for a one-off realisation of capital sums now.

The fact of the matter is that privatisation is an entirely inappropriate approach to the social, economic and community needs of a country such as Australia. It is an approach promoted by vested interests, sustained by blinkered ideological obsessions and entirely lacking in logic and common sense.

That is a ringing denunciation from the Prime Minister in 1985 of privatisation-something which, of course, senior Ministers have now wholeheartedly embraced. We cannot be sure which `vested interests, sustained by blinkered ideological obsessions' the Prime Minister was then referring to. However, maybe some of the United States and United Kingdom bankers who supported the Australian Labor Party during the recent election campaign will now end up becoming advisers to handle the sales of public enterprises. They will not, of course, be imparting their expertise and knowledge free of charge. Their fees and commissions, like everything else, will be paid by all Australians.

I think at the end of the day we are facing a situation where the debate will be carried by the numbers. In the most recent trading on the stock market the reduction in the value of shares in Australia was proportionately greater than that in the United States of America, Britain or Japan. Obviously the bankers, the speculators and the foreign investors whom the Hawke Government tried to please with a balanced Budget and reductions in public sector borrowing requirements still sold their Australian shares in the general panic. I believe it would be difficult in such a market and even probably for the next short while-although our stock market is rising-to sell our public enterprises. Thatcher, of course, has the same problem currently in Britain with her Government's intended sales of the British Petroleum Co. (BP) interests. This has been exacerbated by a whole range of financial problems being experienced by some of the stock brokers who are underwriting the original BP sale.

When one looks at the overview of what has happened recently one is struck by the fact that prior to the stock market fall there was much talk about deregulation. Fascinatingly enough, during the fall the commentators were saying, `Why does not the Government do something and why have not politicians got off their backsides to do a bit of regulating?'. The reason that people say that is very simple: at the end of the day it is the Government that picks up the tab across the board. It is the Government that has to address the public interest. That is why in a democracy we will continue to have governments involved in the operation of the economy.

The reason we should seek to raise the level of this debate about privatisation at this particular time and on this particular Bill is that this Bill addresses semi-government authority borrowings. It is those very borrowings that I believe, as I have set out already, will come under increasing attack in the next 12 months. I think it will be done with a very clear point of view of making sure that, in sufficient time for the Hawke-Keating agenda for this self-fulfilling prophecy, these enterprises are run down in their capital and are in a less fit state to fulfil their functions and hence in a fitter state to sell off. I think that is the type of scenario that we are facing and I think that at the end of the day that will occur. It will occur, however, to the detriment of the Australian public, certainly to the detriment of those who rely on so many of the public enterprises in this country for so much of their livelihood and support. It will be vastly to the detriment of people living in the rural areas of this country. It will be to the detriment of the revenue ultimately and to the detriment of a country which has found it necessary to use public enterprises to provide a level of services to a small population on a vast continent.

It is important for all of us to address ourselves very clearly to this issue. Hopefully those people in the Government who are opposed to the way that the Cabinet is going will make their voices heard in this debate so that it is not simply carried by default as so many other important items have been carried by default-simply by turning the Government's policy on its head so that that with which it went to the people, the policies it espoused at the time it asked for the vote, are simply jettisoned in the wholehearted scramble to please the next lot of donors to the Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Bill. I do not think much need be said about the latter because it is simply a mechanism for the collection of the levy and it provides for certain administrative arrangements in relation to that collection. It is the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill that I want principally to address this evening because this Bill, although very modest in its stated objectives and certainly minuscule in terms of achieving a contribution to government revenue, does have a role to play beyond its apparent significance and does, I think, deserve to be treated seriously, although, as has already been indicated, the Opposition does not oppose these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that the purpose of the Bill is to impose a levy on the borrowings of a range of semi-government authorities, and 21 of these authorities are in fact listed in the schedule to the Bill. The legislation is concerned essentially with the larger State-owned enterprises, the public trading enterprises-the ones with which we are very familiar in the context of the privatisation debate. Only 12 months ago the Government introduced a guarantee charge which attached only to those borrowings that had an explicit guarantee. Of course, what inevitably happened-it would not have taken much foresight to have anticipated this-was that not all Commonwealth borrowings in these areas were necessarily the subject of explicit guarantees and, as a result, were not caught by the legislation. It is not clear to me why this is so, but I simply draw attention to the sums of money that will be raised by a combination of the levy and the on-going guarantee charge.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) suggests that the levy imposed by the Bill is expected to raise revenue of some $1.3m in 1987-88 whilst on-going revenue from the Commonwealth guarantee charge is estimated to amount to $7.6m. If that means that the guarantee will cut out at the end of that financial year, it would seem odd that the levy would not be recouping much more than the sum of $7.6m because it is obviously broader in its coverage and is designed to apply to a whole range of direct and indirect borrowings. Therefore, it would seem to me that we are talking about a sum considerably in excess of $1.3m. Even if that figure were correct, it still needs to be said that the game is not worth the candle. Obviously there are compliance and collection or administrative costs that would be rendered necessary by the imposition of the levy.

At the end of the day, if we look at the purpose for which this legislation is enacted-and that is ostensibly to bring into line borrowings by a range of public trading enterprises so that they do not gain any unfair commercial advantage-we would find, on the sorts of revenue figures that are predicted, that the difference must be extremely marginal, given the sorts of revenue figures that are involved with some of these very large trading enterprises. If that is the case, it would certainly seem that if there is any supposedly unfair commercial advantage currently being obtained by some of the larger institutions, it is minimal and probably we should not worry about proceeding in this way. Certainly, I do not think anyone would argue that there should be an equal playing field when it comes to such forms of borrowings and I do not object to that approach. But by introducing this legislation we are taking a sledgehammer to crack a nut. What we have here is a form of levy which is very modest in its apparent purpose but which, on closer examination, has the capacity perhaps to raise larger amounts of money. It all depends upon judgments that are made as to the extent of the differential.

It is significant that Telecom Australia took specific objection in its annual report to the sum of $2.2m which had been raised by the application of a 0.5 per cent guarantee. It may well be that Telecom was, in part, instrumental in not only having the guarantee replaced by a levy but also in the amount of the levy being reduced because it is now down to a rate not exceeding 0.125 per cent. It is not clear whether the rate is to be 0.125 per cent or whether it is not to exceed 0.5 per cent. In any event, it is an across the board figure which does not take account of the variations between authorities which have been struck for convenience and which could, quite simply, be marginally increased in the following financial year for the purpose of deriving just that little extra revenue that always comes in handy for governments that are profligate spenders.

It goes without saying that this Government has a desperate need to try to recoup funds from every conceivable source. Given its track record to date, one can only imagine that it will find the need an on-going one. In the last 4 1/2 years since it came to office, its revenue from this source has risen from something like $44m to $78m, an increase of some 75 per cent. So it should be apparent why it has been found necessary to try to take advantage of what seemed to be minor opportunities for revenue raising but which, nonetheless, all make a contribution.

It is my submission that the Government is going about it in the wrong manner. It is not worth while intervening to this extent. This legislation is a form of regulation which requires judgments to be made and those judgments are already ongoing. Very many of the borrowings of these institutions require the approval of the Treasurer. They are subject, no doubt, to the Auditor-General and others who might take the view that they are not acting properly. But in reality, these macrogovernment institutions are of such a size that their borrowings do not need to be guaranteed; they do not need any explicit or implicit support from government.

If capital markets want to take the view that somehow some day there might be a run on one of these authorities, that Telecom bonds suddenly become a risky venture and therefore they need to be propped up, I would have thought that that matter could be pre-empted and obviated well before there are any question marks over their liquidity or financial viability. In other words, it is simply not a realistic proposition to suggest that these authorities will operate in such a manner that a discount or penalty needs to be attached to their borrowing rates. If the market chooses to lend at slightly less than commercial rates, that is a decision that the market would seem to have made quite unnecessarily. One would have thought that those lenders could simply recoup the amount that they charged to all other commercial borrowers and, accordingly, they are shortchanging themselves. To the extent that the authorities are the beneficiaries of such a scheme, it does not at all follow that funds should then go into government coffers.

It may well be that if the view were taken theoretically-I am not arguing for the proposition-that somehow these authorities should be compelled to pay a commercial going rate for borrowings, they could be required to set aside the difference, whatever it might be. In the scheme of things, it would be a relatively minor sum of money. But that is not what should happen here. I simply put that forward as an indication that there are ways in which the problem, if it can be so described, could be tackled. It is simply a non-sequitur to suggest that because there might be some marginal differential, the Government should then be able to recoup funds in the way that this Bill proposes. I would suggest that it is simply a guise for further fund raising; it is another form of financial targeting; and it is quite unnecessary in all the circumstances.

I want to address my remarks in a more general context to the issue of privatisation which can be raised squarely in the debate. At the end of the day, if we want to make these enterprises efficient, if we want to enable them to compete fairly, if we want to ensure that they have equal access to capital markets, far and away the most efficient and effective means of doing that is to put them into the private arena. That can be done in a variety of ways. It is one of the great canards in the privatisation debate that somehow what we are really talking about is a selling off entirely of all or many of the large statutory trading enterprises. There is certainly a case for selling off all of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. The recent case of the Bank of New Zealand selling off 13 per cent of its shares with non-voting rights attaching to those shares and with the ability to move to 33 per cent over the next 12 months or so, is an example of what can be done. What the New Zealand Government has done is virtually privatisation by stealth. It is called corporatisation and involves erecting a corporate structure so that the enterprise is properly valued by the market and is in a position where it can be readily transferred if necessary. But it is a clear recognition that that is the most efficient way of handling the very real and vexed problem of the shortage of capital funds available to public trading enterprises. There is a crisis in this country at present. The Aussat annual report has just been tabled in this Parliament. It is quite clear that in order to fund the second generation of satellites Aussat will need approximately $600m. It simply does not have it. It has been down on its knees pleading for access to capital markets for some months now.

In this very chamber last Thursday I asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) whether it was true that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation had a submission before the Government seeking approximately $150m for capital funding because it is short. It is unable to operate in the export markets in the way all the other banks have done. Nonetheless, the best the Minister could say was, in effect, reading between the lines, `This is a sensitive issue. I am not sure that I can disclose publicly just what progress has been made'. The fact of the matter is that that submission has been before the Government for at least two months and no action has been taken to date. The Commonwealth is in desperate need if it is to compete, if it is to be able to get out there and expand instead of just trailing along with some of its major clients and establishing branch offices in other countries. If it were to take a lead from its major competitors it would find that they are very much getting out into the export market and are acquiring overseas banking corporations-the Australia and New Zealand Bank is taking over Grindlay's Bank Ltd and the National Australia Bank Ltd is taking over a couple of Scottish banks. It is the way to go. If we are talking about a global market for banking services, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation is being left far behind. The reason for this is simply that it does not have the funds to enable it to expand.

One could go through a number of these major authorities. There is no doubt that Australian Airlines is a classic example. Not so long ago in this chamber we had a debate about the critical need for funding for Australian Airlines. The fact of the matter is that in the same week that Ansett Airlines of Australia announced that it had embarked upon a $1 billion purchase program of new aircraft, we had the very sad spectacle of the managing director of Australian Airlines returning from overseas after having successfully pleaded for a 10-year deferment on the purchase of some $650m worth of new aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which airline do you travel on?

—I travel Ansett, Senator, but I do not really think that is raising the level of the debate very high. That is the sort of prejudice and blinkered thinking that bedevils a lot of this debate. If we are going to talk in terms of hypocrisy, I cannot do better than to refer to the one-sided presentation by Senator Macklin. I am not referring to him as the arch hypocrite, but it was very significant that he quoted what he described as the ringing denunciation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1985 of the whole concept of privatisation. I am sick and tired of the Prime Minister and others of his ilk berating the Opposition and anyone who has the temerity to discuss the subject as somehow blinkered ideologues, those who are pandering to vested interests and those who are catering for the vested interests of the wealthy.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that we have had a Damascus conversion on the part of the Prime Minister in recent weeks. It is quite clear that the economic rationalists in the Government fully understand the virtues of privatisation. This is not-I repeat, this is not-a sterile economic blueprint. It is not simply a debate for the sake of who can present the toughest program to the people or who can best benefit a small clique of private sector friends and associates. What privatisation is about in its many manifestations is the introduction of competition and efficiency in the market-place for the benefit of consumers. I would have thought that if the Government is interested in consumer sovereignty, then it would be very interested in ensuring that consumers are able to gain the goods and services that are provided, quite unnecessarily by the government sector, by many of these large trading enterprises. The consumer is entitled to receive the benefits of those services at the lowest practicable cost. It is, again, a gross distortion of the arguments in the debate to suggest that somehow the Government needs to remain intimately involved because there are what are called community service objectives.

The reality of the matter is that some very nebulous social objectives are spelt out in various charters. Certainly the Commonwealth Bank has a form of words that I would say would not last five minutes if one were to try to impose a legal obligation on the bank. Similarly, Telecom Australia and Australia Post have forms of words which have enabled them to shelter behind their monopoly positions, but there is no need for those community service obligations to mean that there is a need to retain all the various commercial activities under the rubric of government.

It would be a relatively simple matter to privatise the community social objective. It could be done by a direct government subsidy. That would not be one-way traffic because one would have little doubt, I think, that these enterprises would prosper in the private sector and would, therefore, generate increased revenue. As a result more taxation revenue would be available to government. That would be one mechanism that would be readily available to government. The other mechanism is simply a levy to pay for the cost of those social obligations. In the case of Australia Post, I think the levy is approximately $80m to $100m and in the case of Telecom it is probably around the $500m mark. It is arrant nonsense to suggest that because it might cost approximately $15,000 to install a telephone in a remote area somehow there is a social obligation on government to provide that service. I do not accept that proposition and I do not think it is too harsh to say to those people who choose to live in remote areas that either the Government accepts an explicit political commitment for all sorts of reasons to provide publicly that sort of money, or one goes without or pays for it oneself. It may well be that there will be ways in which those remote communities can combine together to obtain those additional services. At the moment approximately 91 per cent of households have telephones connected. We are left with the very expensive and very remote areas at the bottom of the range.

Telecom quite readily accepts a so-called obligation to move to 100 per cent coverage, but it would certainly be my view that that is most unlikely. It is not just in the remote areas that the difficulty will arise; there are many people at the lower socio-economic end of the market who will not, or simply cannot, afford the sorts of telephone services that the great majority of the population take for granted. But that should not be a reason why there are not very many aspects of Telecom that could not readily be privatised. It does not follow that one has to be in favour of selling off the entire operation; indeed, even to sell off the entire market capitalisation of the Commonwealth Bank until the recent fall would have required sums of approximately $2 1/2 billion to $3 billion which is no small amount of money, and is probably more than had been involved in capital raisings over the last 12 months in any event. It is not necessary to have total privatisation, nor is it feasible in the short term for Telecom to be privatised. Many services are provided, whether they be customer premise equipment, value added services, the first fame monopoly or installation and maintenance. There are all sorts of ways in which Telecom services can be effectively and competitively provided and, quite probably, at significantly cheaper rates to the consumer.

I utterly reject some of the spurious and self-serving criticisms that are made of the concept of privatisation. In many respects the public sector unions are the most vociferous and vocal in defending those monopolies. The real conservatives in this country when it comes to the privatisation debate, the real ideologues, are those who have a direct vested interest in preserving their positions. One can understand that a Telecom technician does not want to be put out into the cold real world because it may turn out that Telecom had been featherbedded, that there was overservicing or overstaffing and that somehow attrition may be required. That may be so. One does not wish it upon anyone, but I would have thought that it is also the case that nearly all those people could earn a very decent living if they were prepared to get out and compete and not take advantage of weekend hours, double rates and all the other rorts and rip-offs that have been such a significant feature of public sector activities in many areas. It is not simply a criticism of any union or any public trading enterprise, it is a function of the protective cocoon in which they have been allowed to operate.

One can just as easily draw an analogy with the high levels of protection that have operated in this country for so long. I think it is now a bipartisan view that that has had a very deleterious consequence for the Australian economy because it has discouraged real competition and it has encouraged those who have the benefits of protection not to compete as heavily, effectively and creatively as they might. The same applies to very many of these public trading enterprises.

These Bills relate to a new scheme of funding provided by the Government to replace the original guarantee arrangements. I wish briefly to address myself to two issues. That Telecom preservation society has on it two former Telecom employees, and one other who presumably very much believes in protecting Telecom from any semblance of competition. It is symptomatic of the way in which the Labor back bench is now moving to take control of those Ministers in the Government who can see some virtue--
—We hope you learn something from that. Do something on your own side.

—We do not have those sorts of factional chasms, but there are some enlightened persons in some statutory authorities, even to the extent that whilst Telecom undoubtedly does not believe in privatisation it has been urging the Government to lift a number of significant restraints that are limiting its capacity to expand and compete in the international sector. I refer not only to the overly generous superannuation and workers compensation schemes-and Senator Walsh no doubt has his own views on the way in which we can reform workers compensation arrangements at Commonwealth level-but also to the WorkCare scheme. I hope that Senator Walsh has not been tempted to go down the same track as the Victorian Government with its disastrous WorkCare scheme which has now blown out to the extent of $2.4 billion. Let that be an object lesson to those who believe that one can simply have a monopoly insurer guaranteeing efficient provision of services.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks on privatisation by saying that I hope there is an element of bipartisan recognition that we are concerned not about an ideological binge, not the sort of double flipping and backtracking that the Prime Minister is engaged in, monumental hypocrisy, but a recognition that there are very real and genuine competitive benefits to be derived from exposing public sector enterprises to private sector competition. The notion of efficiency should be dear to the hearts of all those in government and even those on the other side of the chamber who are concerned to ensure that there is no reduction in the level of funding of welfare services. There would be more dollars to go around if there were more efficient provision of government services by a number of public trading enterprises.

I conclude my remarks on these Bills by referring to an article I came across during the dinner break which gives an insight into the Government's motivation for this current legislation. In a report in the Australian Financial Review of 28 August last Anne Davies said:

The Expenditure Review Committee is believed to be considering a proposal to charge Telecom for implied guarantees on its borrowings, as it attempts to find additional revenue for the September Budget.

Telecom already pays 0.5 per cent on borrowings for the explicit Government guarantee on its inscribed stock but has recently been looking at ways to lower the cost of funds by devising instruments which would not require the explicit guarantee.

It is quite clear that this legislation pre-empts those imaginative manoeuvres by Telecom to avoid an explicit guarantee and so to extend the notion of a levy as to catch all direct and indirect borrowings by public trading enterprises. Telecom has been shafted very quickly and it is legitimate for it to have been concerned because Telecom took the view that if the 0.5 per cent charge on all its borrowings had remained in place, it could have been up for a bill of $6m in this financial year and by 1988-89 would have been paying some $11m. That is not chickenfeed. It makes a significant contribution to government revenue and highlights the real reason for the introduction of this legislation.

There is no need to go tinkering around with all sorts of government interventionist requirements for accommodation costs and supervising costs simply to ensure that somehow this marginal differential between the cost of borrowings in the private sector is entirely equivalent to the cost of borrowings by public enterprises. The real motivation for this type of legislation is to provide more revenue to government coffers. In my view, whilst the Opposition does not oppose these Bills, we should clearly recognise the underlying motivation.

The Government has taken Telecom's complaints to heart to the extent that it has backed away from a fixed half of one per cent charge, which does not take account of the differentials that apply to smaller enterprises which presumably might be asked to pay a slightly higher charge as opposed to those mega-institutions such as Telecom with about $13 billion worth of assets which by no stretch of the imagination could ever be considered vulnerable and therefore should be treated as absolutely safe, no risk investments. There is no reason why institutions should provide Telecom with cheaper financing. The Government should make it abundantly clear that it does not provide any implicit or explicit guarantee, and therefore leave it to the private sector to extract whatever interest rates it can legitimately derive across the board without making any special arrangements for Telecom. If it did that, of course, it would forgo the revenue which in this first instance is relatively modest. But if Telecom's worst fears are realised-and I suppose the way in which the Government has gone about its profligate increases in revenue over the last 4 1/2 years may mean an increase of some 75 per cent-Telecom may well find that it is paying some $11m a year simply by virtue of this seemingly harmless little levy.

I hope that we all realise the true nature of this type of legislation. It is not an exercise in government efficiency. It is an exercise in garnering revenue from wherever the Government can get it. This is simply a first instance and no doubt it will be increased over time. It will be very difficult to unravel the real cost of borrowings to every public sector institution. The Government will then strike a uniform rate, increase it slightly, and rub its hands at the thought that somehow it has managed to extract even more revenue, which was not necessary in the first place.
