TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill repeals the Primary Industry Bank Act of 1977 which, of course, is now redundant following the sale of the Government's interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. PIBA was also granted a banking authority under the Banking Act on 30 June 1987. The sale of this bank was completed on 30 June and resulted in revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.5m. The Opposition is not objecting to the privatisation of the bank as part of the Government's asset sales program. However, it should be noted that the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia is owned by the Government of Western Australia which a lot of people in the community may not know. The Opposition would have preferred to see the bank sold to the private sector rather than to another government instrumentality, whether it be a State or Federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: The timing of the passage of this Bill highlights the lack of foresight and planning in the matter of privatisation. In 1985 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said on the subject of privatisation:
It is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia.
Yet the same Prime Minister, despite the objections of his own Party, has now said:
Certain (Government) holdings that could have, and no doubt did, make good sense in earlier times are not necessarily appropriate for current circumstances.

So after years of criticising the Opposition over privatisation the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have been forced to admit that there is a proposal. It is now only a matter of determining whether the Prime Minister and the Treasurer can make their own Party see sense. From present indications, I believe that this seems very unlikely. However, despite the trauma in the Australian Labor Party over the privatisation matter, there is hardly a murmur from within the Party over the assets sales which are, in effect, a form of privatisation. Why is this being done at this particular stage? I believe the Government is using its assets sales as a ploy to hide its blatant lies about the state of the economy.

Firstly, the Treasurer tried to convince the Australian people that he had brought down a balanced Budget-only $23m in the red. He failed to take into account that this assets sale-a one-off measure-is included in this figure, as is a dividend from the Reserve Bank-another one-off-to finance his so-called `balanced Budget'. If he were honest he would admit that the Budget deficit is closer to $2.5 billion and not the $23m for which he is aiming. The Treasurer has constantly stated that the Australian economy is improving. Yet as soon as the long-expected collapse of the world share markets hit, what happened? The Australian share market fell further than all others, the Australian dollar immediately fell 5c against the US dollar and even further against the other world currencies. Therefore, it would seem that the Government's confidence in the Australian economy has been misplaced and the underlying problems, about which the Opposition has been telling the Government and the Australian people, are about to loom very large on the economic horizon.

However, the sale of the bank again highlights the point that paying off the deficit cannot come from one-off asset sales such as this. It must come from a cut in overall government spending. Until the Government takes action that will cut overall Government spending and reduce the enormous foreign debt, asset sales such as this remain a cosmetic, ineffectual action. Under this Government the gross external deficit has reached almost $110 billion. It has almost trebled since 1983. The current account deficit figure for September was a staggering $1.35 billion. Prior to the Hawke Government coming to power in Australia, this country had never seen a monthly current account deficit of more than $1 billion. Under this Government the figure has been regularly above this point and at one stage the current account deficit was over $1 billion for 14 months straight. Australia's credit rating has been lost by the Hawke Government-it has gone from the highest AAA rating. Once lost this will never be regained. Until the Government adopts policies that will redress these serious imbalances and cut spending to a reasonable level, no amount of asset sales can get Australia out of the problem that it is now in.

The Primary Industry Bank of Australia was set up in 1978 by the Fraser Government specifically to provide long term funding to the rural sector. It is interesting that in this place we have Senator Short, who played a vital part in the setting up of this bank when he was working for one of the government departments in Canberra. It is also interesting for the people in the community to know that it was the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, who, as the Minister for Primary Industry at the time, played a significant role in setting up this bank. The bank achieved a lot in the first instance because it put a ceiling on interest rates. Other banks were not worrying about raising the ceiling for people in primary industry. I will quote from the then Treasurer, Phillip Lynch, in his second reading speech on the Primary Industry Bank Bill in 1978. He said:

The Government's primary consideration in providing for the establishment of this new facility has been to devise a way of enabling credit to be made available to primary producers, including fishermen, for significantly longer terms than has generally been available.
He continued:

The cash flows from (such) investments frequently take some years to reach their potential, but then have life expectancies for many years. Under these circumstances producers can be discouraged from embarking on many worthwhile projects by the relatively short repayment terms often required by traditional lending terms.

The traditional lending terms at the time were between three and six years. When the Primary Industry Bank came into being it extended those terms to 20 years and more. This was a part of the government of the time trying to help young farmers and primary industry, which produces so much for this country, through the young farmers establishment scheme. The PIBA has been a very important aspect of rural finance. Funding continues to be provided for agricultural land purchase and improvement, pasture improvement, livestock purchase and working capital. It has done a great job.

Ten years later, given our dire need to stimulate industry and export income, it is unfortunate that subsequent government policy has, perhaps, limited the effectiveness of the PIBA. However, the bank has consistently given the best interest rates available to the rural industry, in keeping with its charter. Recently the bank has recognised the importance of serviceable loans, interest-only loans for the first five years. This was a pacesetter for the other banks. I understand from people who have used the bank's facilities that its paperwork has been done more quickly than has been the case with some of the other banks.

The rural sector has been one of the worst hit sectors by the economic crisis. The combination of low commodity prices, high interest rates, appalling balance of trade figures and the collapse of the Australian dollar has contributed to a most depressing future for the economic viability of the rural industry. The impact of the rural crisis and, in particular, the part played by finance institutions has spurred the formation of a rural credit inquiry by the New South Wales State Government. Yet the rural sector has consistently been attacked by the policies of this Government, which seems still to suffer from the delusion that people from the land live in the lap of luxury. Nothing could be further from the truth.

One change in policy which has had a severe effect on the rural sector has been the removal of the effectiveness of the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme. Income equalisation deposits were introduced by the Fraser Government as a means of assisting primary producers to minimise the fluctuations that occur in their taxable incomes due to seasonal factors and changes in commodity prices. The scheme operated by allowing a producer to make a deposit when income was high and to withdraw it when income was low. Deposits counted as deductions for income tax purposes and subsequent withdrawals were included as taxable income. Income equalisation deposits were low interest deposits and were able to be bought by the Primary Industry Bank, which allowed the bank to have worthwhile capital to lend.

By June 1982, $166m was held in the IED scheme trust account. This quite considerable amount of money helped the primary industry sector to even out its tax liabilities, enabling the farming community to help the people of Australia by providing vital export income. In May 1983, major modifications were announced to take effect from September of that year, which effectively spelt the end of the IED scheme-a sad day for rural Australia. Deposits made after that date no longer qualified for a tax deduc- tion when made, nor were they to be considered assessable income when withdrawn. Therefore, the fundamental income equalisation nature of these deposits was lost. As I said, it was a sad day for rural people.
It is to be hoped that the sale of the PIBA will not be detrimental to the interests of primary producers. In this year's annual report, the Chairman of PIBA is quoted as saying:

With the acquisition of all shares by the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia and the granting of a national banking authority, the Bank now looks to a future of wider diversification of products and services whilst retaining its traditional links with Australian agriculture.

We in the Opposition parties sincerely hope that the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, in its new form, will continue the work of the old. The Opposition, therefore, will not be opposing the passage of this legislation, but I stress that the functions of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia should not be altered. It should continue the success it has demonstrated over the last 10 years of its performance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are addressing legislation to repeal the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977. This has been made necessary by the Government's decision to sell its interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA), which is now the seventh largest nationally operating banking group. At the very outset I would like to set the record straight on the manner in which the Government has handled the legislative process in this instance, as it has in too many other instances. In May 1987, as part of its mini-Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the Government's willingness to sell its interest in the PIBA. On 30 June, the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia acquired the Commonwealth share in the Primary Industry Bank. Some three months later, on 18 September, the Government introduced legislation to repeal the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said just last week in my comments on the annual report of the PIBA, this sets a dangerous precedent for a Government which, on all of the evidence, is intent on privatising Australia's public enterprises. In this case it is worth drawing the attention of the community to what has happened, particularly, as I say, because the Government appears to be intent on privatisation, by one means or another, through a staged process. We should not be fooled. The Government is obviously prepared to privatise in some areas and is quite up-front about it. The Government says, `We will not privatise Telecom'. I do not take a great deal of comfort in that. The Primary Industry Bank is a case in point. It is another example of the Government making a statement about its intention and taking a great deal of time to come up with the legislation to implement it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is government by Press release.

—Yes, it is the old government by Press release technique. The Government's share in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia has been sold off, interestingly enough, to Western Australian interests-certainly to Western Australian Government interests. For those who are interested in banking and who have observed the financial scene in recent weeks, it is not a matter of great comfort. Later I will discuss other aspects of the privatisation issue. This whole exercise is viewed very negatively by the Australian Democrats. We believe that the Bill before us tonight needs to be opposed, not only on the basis of what has happened but on the basis of this Government's intention regarding privatisation, in particular, in regard to assets sales.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government's intention to sell its share of the PIBA was announced in the May mini-Budget it was stated that the measure was intended to raise revenue-$2.5m. This is something which is possible through the sale of assets, it is something which this Government has extended through the sale of other assets and it is something which we in the Australian Democrats are concerned is becoming a pattern. Therefore, we believe that it is something we need to oppose.

To turn specifically to the Primary Industry Bank, I notice from the second reading speech in the other place of the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) that the rural sector will continue to have a voice on the board of PIBA. I also notice that the Minister believes:
PIBA's prime commitment will continue to be towards meeting the funding requirements of the rural sector.

Of course, the Australian Democrats hope that that support for the rural sector will continue to be the raison d'etre for PIBA, but we express considerable concern at recent statements by PIBA's managing director to the effect that PIBA will now be entering into corporate commercial lending while continuing to dedicate `a large proportion' of its activities towards the agricultural sector. With this intention to enter into corporate and commercial lending, I suspect that we might very well find PIBA addressing its activities not so much to the small farmers but rather to the agri-business sector. The Australian Democrats devoutly hope that this will not be the case.

On this point, I think it is important to make some comment on the question of where Australian agriculture should and could be going and where governments, State and Federal, the rural finance sector and farmers themselves need to look in this respect. One scenario is that a few individuals and businesses-often foreign-based or foreign-owned-will be owning most of the productive agricultural land in this country with a continuing emphasis on intensive farming, pesticide high monoculture and the traditional crops and stock-the ones we are used to such as wheat, wool, beef and so on. In this scenario the small family farmer virtually disappears from the Australian landscape. We should never forget that the resource base, the soil in particular, will also continue to disappear and disintegrate. Dangerous chemical residues will continue to be found in our food, our soil and our water and our exports will continue to be at the mercy of the volatile international trading markets.

Another scenario and an alternative which has the support of the Australian Democrats is for governments and rural finance institutions actively to encourage our farmers to adopt farming practices which will lead to a more sustainable agriculture in this country. That is really critical because, unless we can sustain agriculture into the future, one of the most important bases-if not the most important base-of our economy will be gone. Certainly, I would contend that even now agriculture remains the most important base of our economy. By `a sustainable agriculture' I refer to the following definition of this term which is given to us by the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture:

A system of agriculture able to balance productivity with low vulnerability to problems such as pest infestation and environmental degradation while maintaining the quality of the land for future generations. In practice this involves a system which avoids or largely excludes the use of synthetically compounded fertilisers, pesticides, growth regulators, supply stock feed additives and other harmful or potentially harmful substances. It includes the use of technology such as crop rotations, mechanical cultivation and biological pest control and such materials as legumes, crop residues, animal manures, green manures, other organic wastes and mineral bearing rocks.

I do not think anyone in this chamber, or anyone perhaps listening to this debate, would argue that agriculture in this country must be made sustainable, for if it is not it simply becomes another extractive industry, another industry which will not be available to us in the future and another non-renewable resource in the litany of non renewable resources upon which we are basing too much of our economic future. This should not be the case. Through agriculture, properly conducted, we have the opportunity in perpetuity for Australia to be a productive nation and with a strong economic base.

The benefits of sustainable agriculture include the greater likelihood that small farmers will be able to survive economically, thus being to prevent their farms being taken over by agri- business. The enhancement of the soil is particularly important and is possible through ecologically conscious farming practices. A reduction in, and in some cases the disappearance of, chemical residues in our food chain and in our soil and water would provide us with an additional useful marketing advantage on the world scene-a world which is more and more demanding food products which are safe, nuclear free, chemical free and healthy. This demand is increasing. We spend a lot of time in this place talking about how we can increase our exports. We all know that that is what we need to do. There are markets out there, both within Australia and certainly overseas, particularly in Europe.

As I said just last week in speaking on the annual report of the Primary Industry Bank, the New Zealand Government has got right behind its organic farmers in promoting their products and in providing them with a set of standards which can be properly assessed so that the products can be sold on markets which are growing. Australia needs to recognise these growing markets as well.

Greater financial rewards for our farmers and the nation will flow from exports of chemically free and unpolluted food products which are now in great demand. The Australian Democrats reject in agriculture, as they do in other aspects of our economy, the `get big or get out' approach, which is becoming an increasingly dominant viewpoint in this country. Of course, this approach extends also to the farming sector. Not enough is said and understood about the benefits of the genuine enterprise at the family level in the agricultural area. One of the things we know about agriculture is that even at its best it is not an industry in which people can expect a high return from their capital investment. People involved in agriculture need to understand what they are doing if this great industry is to survive and be of economic advantage to Australia.

One of the things that we do not recognise in Australia at the moment is that there are alternatives to the kind of organisation that our rural industries have had. I would like to suggest that the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, even in its new incarnation, would be a strong supporter, for instance, of the development of farmer co-operatives. Farmer co-operatives in our nation have had quite a mixed history. Some in the fruit canning and dairy industries have struggled to survive. As a Victorian, I point out that there are some ongoing instances of this in my State's dairy industry. Others, however-I would like specifically to mention the Ricegrowers Co- operative Mills Ltd and the Namoi Cotton Co-operative-have been considerable financial successes. The Namoi Cotton Co-operative represents a major challenge to the development of agri-business. It provides its members with technical advice, with credit and with agricultural inputs. It transports cotton from the farm to the gin and is involved in local and international sales and in futures trading.

Co-operatives provide opportunities for producers to achieve market strength otherwise prohibited by the very small scale nature inherent in individual family farming. That was recognised in the past with the establishment of some of the older and more recognised co-operatives, as I have suggested, in the fruit and dairy industries. Co-operative endeavours between farmers, and even perhaps between farmers and consumers, may help to develop local communities. As we know, local rural communities need to face some pretty difficult challenges at this time. They can reduce the cost of farming and minimise food price inflation at the same time as they are bestowing these benefits on the producers, the consumers and the local communities. Money can be kept in the local region for reinvestment, helping to generate that regional economic growth.

There are currently over 400 rural co-operatives registered in Australia with assets of over $2 billion. Their general success has in fact encouraged agribusiness raiding, with firms such as the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd and Industrial Equity Ltd poised to absorb the competition. Corporations such as Elders IXL Ltd have made it known that they would be interested in taking over the operations of the larger statutory authorities if they were to be privatised. So, it is important for any financial institution which claimed to be, or was claimed to be, in the interests of Australian agriculture to look very seriously at giving special consideration to the development of rural co-operatives, and in particular farmer and community joint co-operatives, for all the reasons that I have briefly outlined here. Of course, our concern is that PIBA in its new incarnation may very well be motivated in other directions.

Let me return to the Bill. Bearing in mind the stated commitment of PIBA's Managing Director that the bank will continue to dedicate a large proportion of its activities to the rural sector, and the belief of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that such a commitment should continue, I would like to see the bank take the initiative in providing finance for rural projects that will be of long term benefit to this country. Just one such project which comes to mind, particularly since it is a Western Australian project and since it is a Western Australian bank which has taken up the Government shares in PIBA, is an innovative proposal by one Mr Barrie Oldfield who is President of the Western Australian branch of Men of the Trees, a tree farming project. I believe this deserves considerable consideration, if not by PIBA, certainly by some other agency.

Mr Oldfield recently visited Canberra to discuss his proposal, and the total issue of dry land agriculture and the problems associated therewith, with a number of people including representatives from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Soils, the director of the national soil conservation program and the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris). I was pleased to be able to arrange for the screening of a film produced by Barrie Oldfield entitled Wheat Today, What Tomorrow? which a number of senators and members of staff were able to view and which, incidentally, is available from the Parliamentary Library. While the film highlighted the crisis facing Australia's dry land agricultural areas, particularly those in Western Australia, it also contained information on some very positive farming projects involving the development of a variety of trees beneficial to farming and research and development of new products from these trees.

The aim of the tree farming project is to devise a sustainable economic agriculture for the dry land farms of Australia. On these farms every method of good husbandry known would be brought together. In addition, farm product would be diversified and this would require the development of new techniques for harvesting, processing and the creation of new markets. These, in particular the creation of new markets, are cries that we hear constantly and demands that we hear made all the time of our agricultural sector. But that sector needs support. With losses of $94m a year to agricultural production in Western Australia simply because of dry land degradation in that State, the Australian Democrats believe it is crucial to address this urgent problem, and not just in Western Australia. I believe the tree farming project is most deserving of funding from an organisation such as PIBA, particularly when we note, as I have said, that it was the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia which purchased the Federal Government's shares in PIBA.

As I said earlier, the Australian Democrats oppose this privatisation move as embodied here in the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill. We believe it is a quite deceptive move. I have mentioned that it is a fund raising exercise. As the Minister stated in his second reading speech, the sale of PIBA was completed on 30 June 1987 and resulted in revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.5m. It was a fund raising exercise at the expense, dare I suggest, of our rural industries. But it is also a deceptive move. There is nothing in this legislation which demonstrates what fundamental change has been made for a paltry $2.5m.

We have already heard in this debate from Senator Brownhill, with whom I do not always agree. But certainly he put quite eloquently, in the dying stages of his speech, the fact that the Primary Industry Bank has been useful, has supported farmers as it was intended to do in the beginning, has given a great many farmers security, and even those not using it a sense of security that it was there and available to them. As he said, it has been an efficient enterprise backed by government. As he said, the paper work was quick. For goodness sake, that is not something that we often hear about organisations of this nature.

But Senator Brownhill went on to say that the Opposition `hopes' that everything will be all right now that PIBA has been privatised. This is where Senator Brownhill and I part company, I am sad to say. This is typical of the attitude of the Opposition which here, as unfortunately is so often the case, comes together with the Government in their gallop down the track towards privatisation. There is the mythical idea that nothing should be run by government or supported to any large extent by government because it will be far more efficiently done if it is done by the private sector. I do not think that the rural industries of Australia can live on the sort of hope that was expressed by Senator Brownhill on behalf of the Opposition.

Let me point out a couple of additional points that were made in the annual report, of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia which was tabled last week and which demonstrates what the Primary Industry Bank itself believed-I advisedly use the past tense in this case-was important. The annual report states:
Australian farmers are encouraged to ensure that this country's national land assets are preserved in a condition that is conducive to ongoing productivity.

Agriculture is one sector of the Australian economy that can be truly described as being based on a `renewable resource'. It is important that the quality of this resource be maintained for the present and future generations.

(Quorum formed) Having, before the quorum was called, quoted from the annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which says that it is important that the quality of Australia's renewable resource, which is used in agriculture, be maintained for present and future generations, I was going on to say that that is a sentiment which is absolutely endorsed by the Australian Democrats, and is the reason for the comments which I have made in this debate.

I have also, however, in this debate said that the Australian Democrats oppose this Bill as we see this as the thin end of the wedge, as the beginning of the moves towards privatisation, which we are quite convinced are upon us, certainly on behalf of the Government. As far as the Opposition is concerned, it is just sitting there, salivating and wishing it had done this when it was in government, or that it was in government now so that it could do it all the more quickly.

The question is: Where will privatisation stop? At this stage the Government has said that it has only a few public enterprises in its sights-Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. However, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is already there, as Senator Macklin said earlier this afternoon, gloating to the New York bankers about next year's Budget surplus. Here we go again-more asset sales and more privatisation. This is a government committed to deregulation, Budget surpluses, and reduced government borrowings, and privatisation is only a means to that end. The commitment that the Government had to the Primary Industry Bank, one which was begun, as Senator Brownhill said, by a Liberal government, is now gone. I remind the Senate that PIBA's Managing Director has said that PIBA will now be entering into corporate commercial lending. I also remind the Senate of the spectre of agribusiness, which is squeezing out the family farmer and threatening that resource base in Australia. I quote again from the annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which was tabled last week in this place:

Much of Australia's agricultural areas are subject to drought, fire, flood or plagues at some time. It is important to have a bank that understands these potential difficulties and can help when the time comes.

Against a background of seasonal uncertainty and price variations, it is often difficult for a farmer to plan principal repayment without jeopardising future working capital. To this end PIBA can restructure existing borrowings to increase the funds available for working capital.

That seems to be in direct contrast to the plans for the future for PIBA as outlined by the Managing Director. I do not believe that I can stand here, as Senator Brownhill did, and say that I hope this will not be the case. For that reason, and for the reason that the Australian Democrats are concerned about the total move, both in general economic terms towards privatisation and specifically in agriculture, towards a more, if it is possible, exploitative approach to agriculture and to our resource base, the Australian Democrats will be opposing this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill 1987. This is a significant piece of legislation because it is a response to a very dramatically changed economic environment. When the Primary Industry Bank of Australia was established in 1978 there was a much smaller number of banks than there is now, and shortly prior to the dramatic shrinkage of banks that occurred in the early 1980s. Its establishment certainly preceded the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, and I think in many ways has been overtaken by the outcome of that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The bank itself is fairly small beer. The Commonwealth only ever had a 12.5 per cent share, which it sold for $2.5m, so the market capitalisation of the bank was about $20m. I shudder to think what it would be worth on today's market, but a sum of about $2.5m is not likely to make a significant difference to government revenue. One therefore has to ask why the Government has chosen to embark upon this course. It is not accurately described as privatisation, and I suppose it is not any more accurately described as publicisation. The fact is that the Commonwealth's share in the bank has been sold to a wholly owned State government enterprise, the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. I am informed by a colleague of mine that that bank has spent most of its activities in recent times bailing out friends of the Burke Labor Government, including the Swan Building Society and the Teachers Credit Society Ltd, and more recently, providing a $150m guarantee to Rothwells Ltd. Be that as it may, I suppose the Rural and Industries Bank is not likely to go broke in the short term. If it does, Senator McKiernan will be urging the Burke Government to bail it out. But for the time being we have a transfer from one level of government to another, so I do not think that can be properly described as privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But who wants to be the haves of the Western Australian Government?

—I am in heated agreement with Senator Powell. I think she has eloquently articulated the National Party of Australia point of view in many respects. But I do wish to address in my remarks the extent to which it is proper for a government to be involved in the operations of any bank, let alone a bank of this magnitude. Whilst it might have performed very useful services to the rural community in times gone by-its primary objective was to provide long term funding to the rural sector through a refinance facility-the fact is that the farming community is well able to obtain loans, if necessary, at subsidised rates through a whole range of existing financial institutions, not the least of which are a couple of pastoral companies which spring to mind. It can certainly be deliberately or explicitly encouraged by government to do that by means of the tax mechanism. It is not appropriate for the Government to be involved in an institution such as the Primary Industry Bank. I therefore welcome its sale, although it has not, of course, been sold off entirely to the private sector. Nonetheless, I think it is worth congratulating the Government for the actual transfer, although I think its motives deserve to be questioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The bank did have a very complex structure of ownership, and undoubtedly that did cause management control problems. As I have said, the Commonwealth owned 12.5 per cent. Four of the other major banks, together with a consortium of State banks, each owned 17.5 per cent. One can imagine the sorts of difficulties that would have posed in achieving any significant changes at board level. So it does make sense for the Commonwealth to have shed its interest. I only wish the Commonwealth would adopt the same approach in relation to some of the other enterprises that it presently controls. I have in mind Australian Airlines, which is currently being allowed to bleed to death.

I was horrified at the suggestion made by Senator Maguire, before the dinner break, that because one might travel by Ansett Airlines of Australia, somehow that meant one was a captive of that organisation. The reality, of course, is that if anybody should be grateful to the Government at the present time, it is Ansett Airlines. I think one can safely say that it is a mile in front under the present arrangements. It has had the opportunity to buy about $1 billion worth of new aircraft while at the same time Australian Airlines has been forced to defer its purchase of a miserable $650 million worth. The reality is that the Government is not prepared to operate sensibly and to allow Australian Airlines to have that necessary capital injection, or blood transfusion, that it desperately needs. One can understand that, because of all the heroic circus acts that have been performed in recent times by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to achieve a mirage of a balanced Budget. The fact of the matter is that the Government is simply in no position now to find anything like the sort of money that will be needed to bail out a whole range of public enterprises, Australian Airlines being simply one of them.

I regret that more competition was not introduced into that particular market. The decision to end the two-airline agreement was simply something for which the writing had been on the wall for some years. The ultimate outcome was essentially a very conservative result and one which does not reflect credit on the Government. If the Government had the courage of its real belief in competition it would have allowed Air New Zealand to enter our market as we have been allowed to enter its. It would have considered a merger between Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines and it would have allowed that conglomerate to compete both nationally and internationally with Ansett Airlines of Australia, which is no doubt more than happy to accept that challenge. Of course, the reality at present is that Australian Airlines will simply have one arm behind its back.

In the context of the debate on privatisation it is worth briefly recapitulating some of the pseudo-arguments that have been advanced in this debate and the preceding debate in relation to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill. I fear that the Australian Democrats will adopt the position of running a fear campaign, playing on all sorts of xenophobic responses in the community-fear of foreign ownership, of small family farms being taken over and of privatisation simply transferring wealth into the hands of the greedy. The reality, of course, is that if privatisation is properly handled it is a net benefit to the Australian community. All consumers will benefit from greater efficiency in the provision of services. There is absolutely no justification for the Government's being involved in public trading enterprises to the extent that it is now, or indeed at all, by and large.

I found it rather galling to hear Senator Macklin before the dinner break somehow lauding the castigation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of all those who had the temerity to espouse some virtues of privatisation and not then going on to identify the total recant that we have seen in recent weeks. The Prime Minister now, of course, is finding himself being overtaken by events and being locked in by a Caucus that is so scared stiff that privatisation might actually get somewhere that it is now ensuring that its sale of assets committee has more teeth. It is calling on Ministers to explain in explicit terms any justification for increased asset sales. Of course, the Telecom Australia preservation society, of which perhaps not all honourable senators will be aware, has only recently been set up by Caucus. The Telecom preservation committee consists of three backbenchers, two of whom are former employees of Telecom. The sole object of that exercise--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are repeating yourself.

—No doubt, Senator McKiernan is a strong supporter of that committee. The sole object is to ensure that no aspect of Telecom is touched. I think that is regrettable because it shows the sort of fear-mongering and hysteria that can be easily whipped up for political purposes. If only the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were allowed to have the temporary courage of their convictions we might get a bit more honesty into the debate. It is regrettable that two of the more significant parties in this chamber seem to be hell bent on a path of generating fear and concern in the community when it is not justified. I would have thought that all those good right wing members of the Australian Labor Party and certainly the leaders of the machine, the power drivers and generators, would be right behind the Prime Minister and the Treasurer encouraging them in their feeble and late conversion to efficiency and competition. Whether they are likely to succeed is a moot point at this stage, but it certainly would seem that it would be against the endeavours of the majority of Caucus. That is regrettable.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I think it is opportune that the Government has indeed embarked upon a very small measure of pseudo-privatisation, a transfer from one level of government to another of a 12.5 per cent interest in the Primary Industry Bank to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. It is worth taking note of this measure despite the no doubt impure motives of the Government in using this opportunity to garner a very small sum of money, some $2.5m, no doubt again for improper reasons. I say that deliberately because that sum of money has already been included in the assets sales funds that were announced in the May statement and it will simply be used to finance the increasing level of Government expenditure. The Opposition parties have made clear their position on privatisation. We do not have an ad hoc expedient approach to grabbing a few bob here and there.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have an approach; that is your problem.

—This should be a very good learning opportunity for the likes of Senator Richardson, who might have been foolish enough not to appreciate that we in fact have a series of guiding principles. We are not guided by the desire to try to balance the books at all costs.
—Even you can't keep a straight face with that.

—Let me just recite them to the honourable senator chapter and verse so that he will be under no misapprehension. The sorts of guidelines that we propose for the sale of government assets are as follows: Firstly, there must be demonstrable benefits to consumers and/or taxpayers. It should be painfully obvious that this is the case, even to those ideologues on the other side of the chamber who think that all public ownership is right. Of course, Senator Powell's corollary of that is that all private ownership is wrong. What we have in mind is that there may be demonstrable benefits-there is very likely to be a much higher level of efficiency in private ownership than there ever would be under government ownership-to the consumers and to taxpayers who, by definition, would have to provide less funds to government to maintain these operations, even when they were losing money hand over fist. We have had the Aussat Pty Ltd report tabled today which showed a net loss of $17 1/2m. Government is constantly being asked to bail out these enterprises. There is no need for that. If the services they render are somehow worthy of subsidisation there should be a transparency of approach. An explicit subsidy should be provided.
—So you knock it off again in the Budget.

—We do not have to knock it off. If those interest groups are sufficiently persuasive and are able to demonstrate that a telephone to rural areas should be paid for at the rate of $15,000 a throw, so be it. But let us have it up front.
—You have lived in a city all your life. You do not live in a remote area.
—If the honourable senator chooses to live in a remote area she is perfectly entitled to have a telephone connected herself.
—She lives in the left wing of the Labor Party. That is the most remote area in the country.

—That is right. That is completely out of touch. I do not think even a telephone would be able to help those people back to reality. I am sorry to have disturbed honourable senators opposite, but, as I said, the first principle is demonstrable benefits to consumers or taxpayers. The second is that the position and job security of existing employees will be given special consideration and the sale of shares to employees will be encouraged wherever possible. Lest honourable senators opposite think that we are cold and heartless and that we simply want to turn workers out on the streets, the reality is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are ad idem with us on this. They see the very real benefit of employee ownership, of management and employee buy-outs. It makes all the sense in the world to have a direct involvement in the operation of the enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest there be any misunderstanding, we have only to go back to the debate in England last month at the Trades Union Congress where some clown suggested that privatisation was a horrible thing and that when the Labour Party got back into government it should throw it out. What happened? The leadership of the TUC got up and made it abundantly clear that any such attempt would be thrown out of court; that, in fact, privatisation had been a very popular move, especially amongst all those workers who had been able to take up shares. Ninety-six per cent of British Telecom employees took up shares in that corporation despite a trade union encouraged boycott, despite all of the endeavours of the trade union movement to turn the masses against privatisation. The reality is, of course, that the workers saw right through it and took the money.

I have heard criticism today of the way in which the British Telecom float was undertaken. Let me say this: I do not regard it as a perfect outcome for two very good reasons. Firstly, the Office of Telecommunications, Oftel, the regulatory body which was established was set up very late in the piece at a stage when most of the major decisions had been taken and when it was therefore not in a position to guide the way in which the restructuring took place. The other very significant reason why that float has had a less than optimum result is that the single competitor of British Telecom, Mercury, has been given only a guaranteed 5 per cent of the market with a further guarantee of 10 per cent within five years. That is simply not adequate. If we are talking about real competition in the burgeoning telecommunications industry, which will provide enormous export opportunities for Australia as well as the United Kingdom and other countries, the first thing we have to do is make sure that there is real competition. At the moment it is a very one-sided operation with British Telecom having 95 per cent of the market.

If honourable senators have any sense of history they will go back to the original Bell Corporation that preceded American Telephone and Telegraph Co. in the United States. Whilst there was a government monopoly relatively few telephones were connected. As soon as that monopoly was broken down towards the end of the century that industry exploded. The same has happened since 1984 with the break-up of American Telephone and Telegraph, and I am sure we will see the same situation in Australia. It is not selling the country down the drain; it is not selling consumers down the drain; it is not playing into the hands of vested interests. It is simply ensuring that the consumer is able to get the best value for money and, to the extent that there remains the same amount of money in government coffers, that that money can go further. We could do away with middle class welfare; we could help those people who are genuinely in need. We could be more efficient, and it is a tragedy that the Australian Democrats do not see it in those terms.

If the Democrats were genuinely concerned about ensuring that the government dollar went as far as it ought to go in meeting the very real needs of many Australians who are genuinely disadvantaged and who need government assistance-not simply the unemployed but all those on welfare pensions who are entitled to them-the best way of ensuring that governments will not come under pressure to cut back across the board is to ensure that the services they provide are efficiently provided and that more money is left to go further. That is one of the cardinal principles that lie behind our commitment to the concept. We very much want to see employee interest not just in public trading enterprises; we would welcome it very much at the private sector level, at the enterprise level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you privatise the railways?
—If Don Dunstan thought it was good enough to sell off the railways, we would be interested in the concept.
—Would you actually do that?

—There would be no objection in principle to selling off a loss operation. I would have no problem with selling off Aussat Pty Ltd, which is losing money at the moment. There would be no particular reason why Australian National should not be sold off. There is no particular reason why the Government should shy away from selling off a profit-making enterprise. The principles that are applied do not depend upon the bottom line; they depend upon the nature of the activity. As the Prime Minister said recently, one has to ask first of all: can the service be prepared by the private sector and, if so, can it be better performed by the private sector? That is the reality of the matter, not whether it is making a quid, not whether the Victorian Government should have a 25 per cent stake in Alcoa, not whether it might have a boom year and get back a record return and therefore the Government should hang on to it or whether the following year it has a loss and the Government should be tempted to sell it. That is irrelevant. What is important is that taxpayers' funds do not go towards subsidising activities that can be much better carried out in the private sector and where the real risk takers should be.

SPEECH.PARA: The third principle that we believe is fundamentally important is that the quality and availability of services to remote areas should not be allowed to deteriorate. That means that the community service objective that is written into a good deal of legislation that currently involves cross-subsidisation arrangements can be preserved, that that can be explicitly acknowledged, and to the extent that it requires the transmission of government funds, those funds can be forthcoming. But that is absolutely no reason why cross-subsidisation should be allowed within the enterprise. For example, Telecom Australia is recognising just that fact by breaking itself down into five separate corporate groups. That makes sense because one is able to identify those areas which make a loss, tell precisely how much it is costing the taxpayer and make a sensible political decision whether it is worth while.

It may well be that a much greater contribution should be made to remote areas than is being made at the moment. The blind notion that somehow everyone ought to have a telephone today will be translated into the equally blind notion that tomorrow everyone should have a television set. No doubt the argument could go beyond that in the not too distant future. The real question to be asked is when should governments stop picking up the tab for such activities? If people choose to live in country areas, it does not axiomatically follow that they should be entitled to all of the services that are perhaps taken for granted in some country areas. To the extent that they are necessary for the public good, there may well be a case for government subsidy. Otherwise, I would have thought that the choice should be a private one, not a public one.

The fourth principle we regard as important is that any large scale sales should be timed so as to avoid disruption of capital markets. There was a very clever piece of legerdemain in the United Kingdom last night where the Chancellor of the Exchequer did not shy away from the sale of British Petroleum despite the dramatic downturn in the market. He came up with what would seem to be a very clever manoeuvre. The buy-back arrangement, under which the Government buys shares at 70p, is putting a very real floor under the price. Immediately that was announced the price of the shares already publicly traded went up by about 10 to 15 per cent. That simply shows that the Government was prepared to acknowledge that these are difficult times, and so any Australian Government should recognise that we cannot seek to dump a very large enterprise on the market irrespective of prevailing conditions. It may well be that the Government would want to sell in tranches. It may want to sell only a portion and it may well want to stage the selling off of various aspects of the enterprise. But to the extent that it would involve significant capital raising, the Government would obviously have to take account of the state of the market.

The fifth basic principle we believe is important is that sale proceeds will not be used to finance new government expenditure but will be directed towards reducing the accumulated public debt. That lesson has not been universally applied even in the United Kingdom and it certainly has not been applied here. In this instance the Government could not resist the temptation to use even with the miserable $2.5m on Budget to finance its expenditure excesses and to count it as part of its asset sales for the purpose of achieving a so-called balanced Budget.

Whilst we do not oppose this Bill and whilst in many respects we welcome the decision to sell off the Government interest in the bank, it is regrettable that it will simply go to a State owned or government bank. The Government does not seem to have applied the proceeds in a proper manner and it does not seem to have learnt the lesson that there should be a reduction in expenditure rather than simply a transfer of resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill, which is a relatively short Bill of no more than two pages. The legislation seeks to repeal three Acts of Parliament relating to the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) and to make some consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959. We on the Opposition side believe that the sale of the Government's 12.5 per cent interest in the Primary Industry Bank, which was announced in the May economic statement, is a step in the right direction away from the Federal Government having a direct involvement in the banking system. The sale of the Primary Industry Bank to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia will consolidate the base of the bank and the group will now represent the seventh largest banking organisation in Australia. The new arrangements should enhance the ability of the new institution to assist primary producers and other elements of the rural sector. We note that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in his second reading speech, made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth has sought to ensure that the rural sector would not be disadvantaged in its access to banking services previously provided by PIBA and that the rural sector would continue to have a voice on the PIBA board.

I hope this concern will be an ongoing one and that the Minister will continue to take an interest in the best interests of the rural community. I refer to some comments by the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Ian McLachlan, who stated:

. . . the proposed change in shareholding of the bank should be seen as an opportunity to encourage self-help initiatives for the farm sector, while retaining the bank as primarily a specialist rural lending facility, with at least 60 per cent of all loans being directed to primary producers . . .
Mr McLachlan went on to state that:
. . . ``PIBA'' bond would encourage farmers to set aside funds to help themselves through times of economic crisis.

On completion of the sale of the Government's shares on 30 June this year, the Commonwealth received $2.5m in revenue. I think it is to the credit of the Primary Industry Bank and its executives that last year it achieved its goal of repaying in full the assistance it received from the Commonwealth in the form of loan funds. It was also a very successful year for the bank, with its net profits reaching a sum in the vicinity of $4.25m. This represented an increase of some 22.5 per cent on the previous financial year's profit. I feel sure that all who have been associated with the Primary Industry Bank in the past and those with newly found interests will hope that this new organisation continues its record of success and goes from strength to strength.

I believe that it is appropriate in discussing this Bill to make a few brief points about the banking system generally and how it is operating. Under the deregulated system with a greater number of banks operating in Australia, a number of us are a little disappointed that interest rates have not fallen as much as we would have hoped. However, of late interest rates have tended to show some sort of volatility. Although they have been coming down, we noticed that in the last few days they have firmed slightly as the value of the Australian dollar has slipped in terms of international currency.

However, there is less uncertainty about what I may refer to as the direction bank charges are taking. There is no question about that, for they are going up. Few people tend to realise this until they study their bank statements very closely. Not only do cheque accounts which are held with most of the trading banks attract what is termed accounting charges for each quarter, but also transaction fees are levied. Few people would know that one of Australia's major banks actually charges a fee of 4c per $100 on all deposits; in other words, one pays for the facility of putting one's money in that bank. Most other banks charge a fee where a depositor exceeds perhaps 30 or 40 transactions over a three-month period. This charge is usually 20c per transaction over the maximum limit. While in most cases this fee is levied only where the limit is exceeded, I know of one bank in particular where a depositor was charged for all the transactions where he or she exceeded that limit by only one transaction. I believe that we seem to be reaching the stage where it is becoming more expensive for some people to contact their banker than it is to contact their country solicitor.

The past few years have seen quite rapid changes in banking in Australia. The way that people are organising their money and are paying their bills has changed in that time. This is largely the result of not only technological developments, but also deregulation of the system and a whole lot of new financial institutions. However, there are perceptible changes. I believe that banks must rationalise even further if they are to survive. I think this rationalisation will have to be carried out fairly quickly at the bottom end, and here I am referring to the credit union area and, to a lesser extent, building societies and so on. There will certainly be rationalisation in the financial services area in the next few years. The decline that we have seen as a result of the depressed prices on the stock exchange will, undoubtedly, accentuate that change.

On the whole, all of these changes-electronic transfers of funds, et cetera-have been to the customer's advantage. Convenience is now the watchword of the industry. But there is, however, one area that I believe deserves more attention. It seems that, in some cases, the banks are not accepting their full legal responsibility for error or even convenience. I refer here to the electronic transfer of funds. I do not think the law is quite abreast of current practices in this area and the people who tend to suffer are the customers of the banks. Many people are being unnecessarily inconvenienced in backlogs in the system and are being told, as it were, `It is just one of those things'. We tend to blame the computer. But all banks should be doing all they can to ensure that depositors have access to their funds when they need them.

I think it is also opportune, in discussing this Bill, to examine some other government financial institutions. I refer particularly to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. For example, the annual report which was tabled last week showed the Commonwealth Bank group profit had declined quite significantly last year compared with 1985-86. In fact, the group's operating profit for 1986-87 was $378.1m, or 15 per cent down on the previous year, while the after tax profit was $197.2m, which was 32 per cent lower than 1985-86. This slide in profit is more significant if one looks at the figures for the main company in the group, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, whose profit was down by something like 40 per cent over 1985-86. The annual report remarks that the increase in the corporate tax rate to 49 per cent, together with this Labor Government's fringe benefits tax which actually cost that group $25.7m last year, contributed significantly to this diminished profit.

These great taxation burdens that are the handiwork of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, have severely disadvantaged the banks despite the first class efforts of the Chairman of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Sir Brian Massy-Greene, in conjunction with the Managing Director, Mr Don Sanders, in managing this operation it was noted that these sorts of charges were beyond the control of the executive and the board. Despite the problems that are in the economy at the moment, we wish the new and enlarged Primary Industry Bank every success.

I mentioned earlier that banks must rationalise to survive. I think people's perception of the banking community has undoubtedly slipped in the last few years. Basically the banks really have not appreciated, or certainly they have underestimated, the extent of corruption in the banking system, particularly so far as tax avoidance and tax evasion is concerned. I believe that the banks, therefore, have to tighten up their act very much more, otherwise there will be some Federal legislation in this area.

The decision about last September by private banks to charge customers a fee for withdrawing their own money from savings accounts has been described as greed. Steps such as this have indicated a certain amount of greed. Undoubtedly, the deregulation of the banking system has caught up with a lot of these banks. They have made their initial cost savings. They are now competing on a more open market and there is certainly pressure on their profits. But I think there will be further substantial changes in the bank structure of Australia if banks are to survive this tough economic climate in which we find ourselves today. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to legislation affecting Australia's meat and livestock industry, namely, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977; the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985; the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984; and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984. This Bill is associated with the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987 and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987.

In regard to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, the Bill formalises the ability of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) to work with the Australian Pork Corporation in the development of marketing schemes for Meat and Livestock. Provision is made for the Minister to prescribe by Regulation individual marketing schemes such as computer aided live-stock marketing, known as CALM, and the Authority for the uniform specification of meat and live-stock known as AUS-MEAT. The Bill also provides that the AMLC will be required to consult with the peak industry bodies in the preparation of its five-year corporate plan and its annual operational plan. In addition to the five-year plan is to be a rolling plan, that is, it will need to be updated each year so that it always covers the next five years.

A number of specific additions are made to the information to be contained in the AMLC's annual report; these are intended to improve the level of reporting by the Corporation to Parliament on its activities. The powers of the AMLC to meet the costs and expenses incurred by industry organisations attending consultations with the Corporation are clarified. The AMLC will be able to make payments in addition to travelling expenses, in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister. These guidelines make it quite clear that only reasonable costs associated with consultations can be met, and it will be up to the AMLC to ensure that activities for which it meets the costs are consistent with its powers and functions.

The legislation proposes to limit the making of such payments to the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council. There is also, however, a provision for other organisations to be added to the list by regulation, should it become apparent that this is appropriate. Under the current AMLC Act members are appointed for a fixed three year term with appointments being staggered so that not all members change at once. It is proposed to make this arrangement more flexible by providing that members may be appointed for periods of up to three years. A number of changes are intended to streamline the administration and operation of the AMLC's Annual General Meeting. These include greater flexibility in the timing of AGMs, the closing date of voting registers, lodgment of notices of motion and the deadline by which proxies must be lodged. In addition the provision requiring a vote of 75 per cent of those people on the register to pass a special motion or to overturn a Corporation motion for an increase in the levy, is to be changed so that a vote of 75 per cent of those people present, either in person or by proxy is all that will be required. In line with the Government's policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities, the legislation requires the AMLC to adopt an equal employment opportunities program. This program is to be incorporated in the Corporation's corporate plans and a progress report is to be included in the Corporation's annual report to Parliament.

The Changes to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 are designed to streamline the administration and operation of the Corporation's annual general meeting and mirror the changes being made in this regard to the AMLC Act. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984 is to be amended to remove the requirement that the policy council holds an industry wide conference at least every two years to canvass industry views on matters currently affecting the industry. The policy council will, however, retain its power to call such conferences whenever it feels they are needed.

This Bill also seeks to amend the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984. This Act provides for a selection committee to nominate members for appointment to the AMLC and the AMLRDC. The proposed changes are to allow for the appointment of members of the selection committee for periods of up to three years instead of the present fixed three-year term. Also it is proposed to remove the requirement for the selection committee to prepare an annual report to Parliament. The preparation of an annual report is considered unnecessary as the Committee has only a single purpose and meets on an ad hoc basis. The amendment will bring the selection committee into line with other statutory marketing authority selection committees.
The changes proposed by this Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable senators. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
LIVE-STOCK EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rates of export charge that may be imposed under the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1964. This Act imposes a charge on the export of cattle, sheep, lambs, buffaloes and goats from Australia. As in the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 the charge consists of three components which raise funds to finance the activities of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC), the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC), and, in the case of cattle and buffaloes, bovine disease eradication. Maximum rates are set in the legislation for the AMLRDC component, the disease eradication component, and the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The maximum available for the AMLC is the difference between the current operative rate for the AMLRDC and the maximum rate prescribed for the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The individual operative rates of charge for each class of livestock are set by regulation. The export charge rates for the AMLC and the AMLRDC are varied only after the Minister has received recommendations from the relevant body, that is either the AMLC or the AMLRDC. Neither the AMLC nor the AMLRDC is permitted to recommend a change to the operative rates of export charge without having first had a motion endorsing the changes passed at their respective annual general meetings.

The amendments proposed in this Bill will increase the maximum level of the export charge and therefore the AMLC's potential share of the charge, while not increasing the maximum rate prescribed for the AMLRDC or disease eradication. The proposed increases in the maximum charge rates are as follows:
Cattle-from $6.00 to $18.00
Sheep-from 60c to $1.50
Lambs-from 67c to $1.50
Buffalo-from $6.00 to $18.00
Goats-from 60c to $1.00

The considerations behind the substantial increase in maximum charge rates are the same as I outlined in my speech relating to the Livestock Slaughter Levy. The proposed increases will have no effect on the current operative rates of the livestock export charge, nor will they have any direct impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable senators. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rates of levy that may be imposed under the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964. This Act imposes a levy on the slaughter at an abattoir of cattle, sheep, lambs, buffaloes, goats, calves and bobby calves for human consumption. This Bill is associated with the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987. The levy consists of three components which raise funds to finance the activities of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) including its promotion functions, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC) and, in the case of cattle, calves, bobby calves and buffaloes, bovine disease eradication. Maximum rates are set in the legislation for the AMLRDC component, the disease eradication component and the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The maximum available for the AMLC is the difference between the current operative rate for AMLRDC and the maximum rate prescribed for the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The individual operative rates of the levy for each class of livestock are set by regulation. The slaughter levy rates for the AMLC or the AMLRDC are varied only after the Minister has received recommendations from the relevant body, that is either the AMLC or the AMLRDC. Neither the AMLC nor the AMLRDC is permitted to recommend a change to the operative rates of levy without having first had a motion endorsing the changes passed at their respective annual general meetings.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will increase the maximum level of the slaughter levy and therefore the AMLC's potential share of the levy, while not changing the amount set aside for the AMLRDC or disease eradication. The proposed increases in the maximum levy rates are as follows:
Cattle-from $6.00 to $18.00
Sheep-from 60c to $1.50
Lambs-from 67c to $1.50
Buffalo-from $6.00 to $18.00
Goats-from 60c to $1.00
Calves-from $2.10 to $6.30
Bobby calves-from 60c to $1.80

Substantial increases in the maximum rates prescribed for the livestock slaughter levy have been recommended by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation with general support from the major industry organisations. The levels recommended to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy allow scope for the AMLC component of the levy to be increased to enable the purchase and disposal of meat with a high risk of containing pesticide residues and to finance anticipated expenditure by the Corporation on programs being initiated to avoid a repetition of the recent chemical residues crisis. They also provide scope for the AMLC to seek additional funding for its promotion activities in Australia and overseas.

On the matter of pesticide residues I would like to congratulate the industry on its preparedness to tackle the problem. The industry, apparently universally, accepts the need to get its house in order and to take whatever steps are necessary to re-establish its reputation as a supplier of nutritious product to the world's markets. So far as domestic consumers are concerned, they can be assured that Australian meat remains a healthy and desirable part of a well-balanced diet. The adequacy of the AMLC's present promotion activities was the subject of lively debate at the last annual general meeting of the AMLC. It was apparent at that meeting that there was general willingness to support significant increases in promotion expenditure if the AMLC thought it would be cost effective.

Passage of this Bill will clear the way for the possible introduction of new operative rates of levy if such are recommended by the forthcoming annual meeting of the AMLC. The proposed increases will have no effect on the current operative rates of livestock slaughter levy, nor will they have any direct impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable senators. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 to complement the amendments to the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 which are included in the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill amends the provisions in the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 which prevent the extension of the `continuous registration' initiative to establishments which are subject to establishment registration charge. An explanation of this initiative is given in the second reading speech on the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill also makes general consequential drafting changes.

Other effects of the Bill are to replace a provision describing the time within which various charges are to be payable, so as to leave that kind of detail to be specified in regulations, and to remove a provision which will serve no purpose following the entry into force of amendments to the Export Control Act 1982 which are included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1987. The Bill will have no direct financial impact, as the amount of charge collected will not be affected by the amendments. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
EXPORT INSPECTION (ESTABLISHMENT REGISTRATION CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 to remove impediments to the full implementation of an initiative designed to reduce the red-tape burden on exporters of foodstuffs. The Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 is one of three Acts (the others being the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985 and the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985) introduced by this Government to give as much flexibility as possible in determining appropriate export inspection charging systems for different sectors of the food export industry.

At the time the Act was introduced, export establishments were registered on an annual basis subject to renewal, and the establishment registration charge was modelled accordingly, to be a charge on that registration, payable annually. Earlier this year, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service initiated a system of continuing, or perpetual, registrations, not requiring any renewal. This is attractive as reducing the paperwork for the Service and for industry, and reducing administrative costs in the long run. Because of the inflexible nature of the establishment registration charge, establishments subject to that charge have not been able to participate in that system. These are all establishments involved in the preparation of fish and poultry products for export.

The Bill amends provisions in the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 which prevent the extension of this initiative to establishments which are subject to the establishment registration charge. Under the Bill, the charge may be imposed on a periodic basis and not linked to the commencement or renewal of registration. The Bill also makes several consequential drafting changes. The Bill will have no direct financial impact, as the amounts of charge imposed will not be affected by the amendments. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
