SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I indicate at the outset of my remarks that the Opposition will support this legislation, although we will seek to move one amendment and we will support an amendment which, I understand, is to be moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to do several different things related, in essence, to the operation of the pharmaceutical benefits system in Australia. As honourable senators know, there is a scheme known as Pharmpay whereby the Commonwealth reimburses pharmacists for the costs associated with the dispensing of prescriptions. Under the new arrangements which are proposed in this legislation, the Pharmpay scheme will offer three alternatives to pharmacists. Pharmacists may submit payment application details to the Department of Community Services and Health on compatible floppy disk or via modem for instant processing by the departmental computers. This scheme, which is referred to as the claims transmission service (CTS), is already in operation. Today the situation has arisen where the pharmacists who wish to become participants in this scheme find that they are no longer as well placed as they were just a couple of days ago because they had to decide, prior to 1 November 1987, to become participants in the CTS arrangements. That option has been available since July 1986. By August 1987 approximately 1,700 of the 5,000 pharmacies in Australia had opted to participate in the CTS arrangements.

The second method of payment under the Pharmpay scheme will be for the pharmacist to submit all prescriptions for payment on a random sampling basis. Under this arrangement the pharmacist can select 10 per cent of scripts for payment in full and the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Department of Finance have been involved in establishing various sampling arrangements. I will come back to this in due course as this will be the point at which the Opposition will seek, in the committee stage of the Bill, to move an amendment. In fact, the purport of our amendment will be, in essence, to provide a sunset provision so that the scheme which will operate in relation to random sampling will have a termination date of 30 June 1989. Of course, it will be possible to extend beyond that date, provided the evidence warrants extending beyond that date. In the committee stage I will have more to say about that particular amendment.

Thirdly, the Pharmpay scheme will offer the maintenance of current arrangements on behalf of the pharmacist for submitting all scripts for manual processing on to computers within the Department of Community Services and Health. The Government is providing an incentive for pharmacists who opt for either the transmission of their data on compatible floppy disk or via modem or those who participate in the random sampling scheme. The incentive is provided in the form of a 2.5c per script payment to the pharmacists, although it is made clear in the legislation-in what will then become clause 99aaa(4)(c)-that this scheme will operate only for a two-year period and will then presumably be terminated. The Government estimates that net savings by the use of more computer compatible information or the random sampling scheme will be in the order of $8.6m.

This legislation significantly alters some of the operations and the administration of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The PBAC is to be increased in size from eight to 11 and therefore there will be an increase in the staff which will be provided by way of service to the advisory committee. Of the 11 members of the PBAC, 10 will be doctors and one will be a pharmacist. Although we do not propose to deal with this by way of amendment, I raise the question as to whether there is not something of an imbalance in terms of the relationship between the number of doctors and the number of pharmacists and whether the pharmacists or a pharmacologist or whatever should be provided with more places on the PBAC. That is a point of some concern; I do not in any sense seek to press it. The third point here is that the Government is seeking to address what it regards as the blowout of costs as far as prescriptions and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is concerned. Figures provided indicate that the average price per script was up about 24 per cent over 1986-87 and that an estimated overall increase of 58 per cent to a figure of some $970m from 1985 to 1987 had been in prospect.

One of the ways this legislation seeks to address the question of burgeoning costs is to put in the hands of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) the power to remove expensive drugs from the list. The Minister is given a power to do this and at the same time the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is, for the first time, required by statute to bear in mind the question of the cost of drugs when it recommends the listing of new drugs and to consider what are described as alternatives. The Minister's second reading speech deals with this particular matter. He said:
The obligation-
that is, the obligation on the PBAC-

to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example surgery, in making recommendations. The Committee will not be allowed to recommend the listing of a particular drug which is substantially more costly, unless it is satisfied that, at least for some patients, the drugs provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy.

I believe there are a couple of problems which arise as far as that proposal in the legislation is concerned. I know that Senator Coulter will be addressing some of those problems and will be moving an amendment which, as I have indicated, the Opposition is minded to support at this stage. There is a necessity for the Minister to seek PBAC advice, not just in terms of cost effectiveness when the PBAC is making a recommendation for the listing of drugs, but also when the Minister proceeds to take the opportunity to delist a particular drug. That advice should become publicly available by being presented in some appropriate form to the Parliament.

The point which I raise in relation to this question of attempting to establish some test of efficacy in relation to alternative forms of treatment has several aspects to it. The first is that there may be quite considerable difficulties in adopting a general rule of thumb as far as this matter is concerned. For instance, it may be quite appropriate for surgery to be performed on young, healthy adults in relation to a particular matter. When one looks at the particular circumstances and the particular case, the choice between the use of a long term pharmacological regime and the use of surgery may clearly indicate surgery is the correct way to proceed. But, for a patient of 75 years of age, surgery, with its attendant risks, traumas and difficulties for elderly people, may be inappropriate. I do not claim to be in a position, as my colleague Senator Peter Baume is, to make a professional judgment, but under those circumstances a drug based regime may be the appropriate method and surgery, as I said, may be inappropriate. The Minister, in his second reading speech, says:
. . . unless it-
that is, the PBAC-
is satisfied that, at least for some patients, the drug provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy.

I suspect that there will always be some patients for whom drug based therapy is the reasonable course of action. I do not think that the Government will succeed in imposing very much discipline upon the PBAC in terms of that recommendation because the PBAC will always find significant numbers of people for whom drug based therapy, as distinct from surgery or some alternative form of treatment, is an advantage.
Apparently, there has been a very substantial growth in resistance to the effectiveness of antibiotics. An article which appeared on 30 September in the Australian by John Newell said, in part:

A three-year study by 100 medical experts in 30 countries has revealed disturbing new evidence of the resistance to antibiotics that is spreading among many strains of bacteria . . . Nearly all disease-causing organisms can, it was found, still be treated with one or more antibiotics. But the emergence of resistance often means that the only effective antibiotics are hard to obtain or are very expensive. . .

Although the findings related primarily to what was happening in the Third World, nevertheless it has some serious implications for the approach being taken in this legislation. After all, the PBAC must now take account of the cost of drugs. The growing resistance of bacteria to existing antibiotics means that new and more expensive antibiotics must be used to combat common diseases. If these drugs are not listed on PBAC advice, given that the old drugs may still be effective in this country and the new ones too expensive, we run the risk of resistant strains causing considerable damage to the health of Australians who will have only the old antibiotics rather than the new, expensive and non-listed ones.

I draw attention to the difficulties that will arise for a particular group of people in Australia for whom this is already a major issue. I refer to people suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil, who will also participate in this debate, and I serve on the parliamentary liaison committee on AIDS. One of the things we have noted in our work on this committee over the last couple of years has been, obviously, the very great interest in potential drug therapies for dealing with AIDS. At the moment the most promising drug on the market is AZT. AZT is available in limited quantities in Australia at the moment. The Government has been extraordinarily generous, both at the Federal and State level, particularly with regard to New South Wales, in making money available for clinical trials and for the treatment of AIDS sufferers.

TALK.START.PARA: —But; Senator Puplick, governments are not generous; taxpayers are generous through the agency of governments.

—I take Senator Stone's point, but if one happens to be an AIDS sufferer one does not care who appears to be generous as long as the money is around. However, I accept that it is public money contributed by taxpayers. It is important that taxpayers see that, through the exercise of parliamentary scrutiny, money is effectively and efficaciously spent. The cost of treatment with AZT is about $10,000 a year. We have been warned by the appropriate health authorities in this country, as indicated in an article which appeared in the Medical Journal of Australia quite recently, that the bill for the battle against AIDS, in terms of the total cost of both drug therapy and hospital therapy, may be in the vicinity of $100m by 1990. That is a quite reasonable prediction. Payment will, in large part, be influenced by the extent to which taxpayers are prepared to continue to see the expenditure of sums such as $10,000 a year for the treatment of patients using AZT.

SPEECH.PARA: People will have noted the attempts of Professor Dwyer in Sydney to develop a regime which involves simultaneous thymus gland transplants and the use of AZT. One would hope that we will not reach the stage where every new advance or drug which comes on to the market will be put through the sorts of procedures used by the PBAC in relation to the treatment of AIDS and judgments will have to be continually made. One would hope that because in a purely economic sense the existing regime is more cost-effective a decision will not be made that therefore we will not list a new drug which has come on to the market as part of the benefit system. If that attitude prevails a number of very false economies may be introduced into the system.

Whilst I know that Senator Stone shares with me a desire to ensure that not only is government money effectively spent but also that there is a reduction in government expenditure, I think we would both be prepared to identify a large number of areas where cuts and restrictions could be made which would rank well ahead of necessary life-saving treatment of individual patients suffering from terrible diseases.

I said that we were concerned about some aspects of the so-called random sampling method. When I read the details of the debate in the House of Representatives, I came across the comments made by Mr Lamb, the honourable member for Streeton, on 29 October. He said:

If one studies statistics, permutations, computations and the laws of chance one would realise that under this sampling method there is a nine in 10 chance of a pharmacist being overpaid when the incentive payment is included but I would say that without that payment the costing would almost be spot on.

There may be considerable argument about the validity of statistical methods. As I have always thought that in this business all one needed to do was to be able to work out what was 50 per cent plus one, I have never been overly concerned with the finer points of statistical analysis. Nevertheless, some considerable difficulties arise. We do not seek to defeat the attempt to see whether the use of the proposed statistical method works. However, we intend to seek an amendment to require the imposition, as it were, of a sunset clause relating to payments until 30 June 1989 at which stage we should have evidence before us which will persuasively argue whether the random sampling payment method should be continued or terminated. I cannot see that there would be any objection to having a point at which the matter must be reviewed, at which stage one can see whether the system has worked well, whether the system has worked fairly, whether there have been any rorts in the system and, if there have, whether they have been eliminated, whether they can be eliminated, or whether they are so endemic, as far as the methodology is concerned, that the system should automatically fail by operation of the sunset clause, unless the Parliament is minded to extend the use of a statistical method for some further period.

In the House of Representatives the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Donald Cameron, raised a number of concerns about the power given to the Minister under this legislation to unilaterally delist drugs. I have already referred to that and I indicated that we believe that it would be proper, just as the Minister must receive advice from the PBAC before a drug is listed, for him to receive advice before he unilaterally moves to delist a particular drug and that that advice, which in our opinion is very important advice that he should consider, will not be binding advice. He may decide to ignore the advice which he gets from the Committee but we believe that that advice should be sought, should be considered by the Minister and the Minister should make the details of that advice available to the Parliament by tabling it or presenting it in some form which allows public scrutiny. I acknowledge that the legislation allows the Minister to delist the drugs in such a fashion that the Parliament may overturn the Minister's determination on this matter by disallowing the regulation by which the Minister will proceed to put the delisting into effect.

As I have said, we believe that some particular problems arise as far as this legislation is concerned. Nevertheless, we are at one with the Government in its desire to achieve some cost control within the pharmaceutical benefits system. There is no doubt that it is an enormously expensive system. I think there are also a large number of areas which the Government needs to address, one of which is the extraordinary delays which apparently occur in the reimbursements to pharmacists. The records of the Department of Community Services and Health show that between October 1984 and March 1985 delays in payment times had increased from 28 days to 102 days in New South Wales and there were substantial delays in other States. At one stage it was alleged that there was a backlog of 51 million unprocessed prescriptions. Clearly that is a matter that needs to be addressed.

I suppose that two things arise out of that, upon which comment can be made. The first is that the Opposition will be proceeding with legislation which Mr Tuckey introduced in the House of Representatives in the last Parliament to secure the prompt payment of government debts. That is a matter which needs to be addressed. After all, we are dealing here, by and large, with small businesses, which are particularly disadvantaged by the Government's failure to pay its bills on time. Secondly, one has to raise the question of why the small pharmacists should be required to purchase expensive computer equipment in order to be paid within a reasonable period when the obligation ought to be on the Government to pay its bills on time. It is claimed that pharmacists who use the claims transmission system will get their payments within 20 days; that those who use the statistical method will get their payments within 25 days; and others will be paid within 30 days. All I can say about that is that we are not holding our breath in the belief that the Government will actually manage to meet those targets.

At this stage I have not sought to discuss the whole question of the overall expenditure on the national health scheme. That matter is capable of being debated in the debate which is still in progress on the Medicare levy amendment legislation, which is before the chamber, and I do not propose to open up that line of debate in relation to this piece of legislation.

As I have said, with the qualifications which I have raised and with the potential amendments to which I have made reference, the Opposition will support this piece of legislation, although we will be interested to know how the Government responds to the criticisms which have been raised. We will be particularly anxious to monitor the operation of the new arrangements under the Pharmpay scheme once they actually come into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick has covered several of the points which I wish to make, but I would like to begin by drawing attention to the fact that the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 extends a mode of thinking which I believe needs to be rather more closely examined in the community; that is, that we have been moving into an era of higher and higher health costs, and higher costs elsewhere in the community and as a community, we have not really decided how we wish to divide these costs. At the moment we have some extremely expensive ways of keeping people alive. At the same time, perhaps we cannot find sufficient money to spend on kindergartens and various other things in the community. As a community, we have not really faced this issue. It bears on this piece of legislation because we have here a Bill which is attempting to balance the costs of drugs against the costs of health care. In several places that is clearly drawn out.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick has drawn attention to the fact that the legislation gives the Minister the power to withdraw a drug from the schedule without reference to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. We will be moving amendments to that clause. There is also a shifting away from the area of professional judgment towards the area of cost. While that is legitimate to a certain extent, it does not sufficiently broaden the area of public debate, and we will be moving amendments also to clause 8 of this Bill, under which the Minister has the power to appoint members of the Committee, in an attempt to broaden the representation so that one of those medical practitioners may be drawn from the Doctors Reform Society.
Returning to the first amendment, clause 4 of the Bill will amend section 85 of the principal Act. This clause gives the Minister the power simply to declare:

that a drug or medicinal preparation, or a class of drugs and medicinal preparations, shall cease to be a drug or medicinal preparation, or a class of drugs and medicinal preparations, to which this Part applies.
The clause also states:
. . . the Minister shall have regard to any view previously expressed to the Minister . . . by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee . . .

There is no requirement in that clause that the Minister shall actively seek the advice of that Committee, yet the Committee is being extended by those three extra people and presumably there is seen to be a necessity for better quality advice from the Committee. It seems, therefore, rather inconsistent that the Minister should unilaterally be able to remove drugs in that way. Accordingly, we will be moving the amendment which stands in the name of the Australian Democrats to the effect that the Minister shall be required, firstly, to obtain advice and, secondly, that that advice will necessarily be placed before both Houses of Parliament. Clause 8 of the Bill states:
The Minister may also appoint as members of the Committee:
(a) a pharmacologist; and
(b) not more than 3 medical practitioners in addition to the medical practitioners referred to in paragraph (1) (b) . . .

In that case it seems as though the Minister is completely free to select those medical practitioners. In view of the width of the debate over medical treatment, of drug treatment vis-a-vis other forms of treatment and alternative forms of medical treatment, and the considerable concern in the community that perhaps the community is not being well served in terms of cost and the type of medicine being offered, it would seem appropriate to broaden the representation of the extra members of the Committee. Accordingly, we propose that at least one of those other three practitioners be selected from those nominated by the Doctors Reform Society. Apart from that, the Democrats will support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 covers three matters to which I would like to refer. The first is the cost saving measure to which other senators have already addressed themselves. The second and third provide mechanisms for speeding up the payment of pharmaceutical benefits. I remind the Senate that the system of pharmaceutical benefits was developed and extended by successive Liberal governments over two generations. It was done with the purpose and the aim of giving protection to Australian citizens against unforeseen happenings, initially with life-saving drugs and later with a more extensive range of medications. Over the last few years, both in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and with the similar repatriation scheme, we have seen the steady removal of drugs from the list for which subsidies are payable.

SPEECH.PARA: It is against that background of history that I turn to the first matter, which is that the Government is seeking to contain the cost of more expensive drugs by limiting the availability of pharmaceutical benefits for some of them. The Bill makes specific changes to the operation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) and it provides extra resources for the secretariat to the Committee. But these changes appear to have been made to allow the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to assess what the Government wants assessed, which is whether there are alternatives to the more expensive drugs and whether those are equivalent. I take it that that means pharmacologically equivalent, therapeutically equivalent drugs. Really, the matters to which Senator Coulter addressed himself are matters for another debate.

This Bill is about whether there are equivalents in therapeutic terms. Where there are equivalents in therapeutic terms, it is the intention of the Government that the more expensive drug would be removed from the pharmaceutical benefits list. So far, so good. The Opposition does not object to that approach. But, in line with the traditions of this pharmaceutical benefits scheme, we want to ensure that any action which is taken, that any deletions that occur and that any judgments that are made are in the long term interests of the citizens of this country.

People look to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to give them the protection that they expect whenever they require the prescription of medication for illness, often quite serious illness. Our goal on this side of the chamber is the protection of Australians, and the maintenance of that protection which has been provided by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I will assess any amendments against that goal, that is, that it is the protection of Australians that comes first. If this measure reduces, now or in the future as a result of actions taken following the passage of this legislation, the protection available to Australians, the Bill will have failed in its purpose, whatever its economic consequences. It may save some money but, if in the end Australians are worse off, the Bill will have failed.

So the question I put to the Senate is: How are we to be able to ensure that the cheapest drug will be one that is equivalent in the therapeutic sense or the pharmacological sense? How will the Government ensure this? What are the instructions that will be given to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee when it sets out to do this task? That is the central question. Unless we know how the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee will make its decisions, we will not know how it will construct the advice that comes to government-advice on which the Minister may act. The Government may well have an answer, but I want to know from the Government exactly how it will proceed so that we can know that the drugs under discussion will be drugs of therapeutic equivalence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is equivalent?

—That is a fair question. I hope the Government will tell us in the summing up. It is not our function to answer those questions. It is our function to pose the questions. We are not accusing the Government of anything. We are saying that it is our duty to speak for the constituency which wants to have available to it the best pharmacological agents, the best drugs. It wants to be sure that, in going down this cost-saving path, the Government will make its decisions on some basis which citizens can understand and accept as valid. How will the expansion and beefing up of the PBAC, proposed under this legislation, ensure the outcomes to which I am drawing attention? When it is time to sum up this debate, I ask the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is at the table, or the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), who is responsible for this matter in the Senate, to please give us an answer to the question about the method by which therapeutic equivalence will be assured.

SPEECH.PARA: In that respect I would like to say to Senator Coulter that I read the amendment from the Australian Democrats, the one about which Senator Puplick spoke and which I believe Senator Coulter will move later in the Committee of the Whole. Insofar as it goes, it is fine in that it states:
Before making a declaration under subsection (2aa), the Minister shall obtain the advice in writing of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in relation to the proposed declaration.

What it does not say is that that advice shall include some statement about the equivalence of the therapeutic preparations. Perhaps Senator Coulter assumed that that would be automatically the case. But that advice could be any kind of advice. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee may merely say, `We advise that such and such a drug be deleted'. I suggest to the honourable senator that if his purpose was as I think it was, we will not be sure, even if his amendment is accepted, that the PBAC in providing such advice will do so in a way that provides the evidence we want of therapeutic equivalence.

I turn to the other matters covered by this Bill. The second important issue arises from the Government's announcements about drug pricing generally. This really arises from the first matter. There is an apparent conflict in government policy. I raised this in the Estimates committee hearings and I raise it again now. The pharmaceutical manufacturing industry in Australia deserves a fair go and it will not get a fair go unless the Government's policy and approach is absolutely clear and unambiguous. The key motivation behind this legislation is one of cost-the cost of therapeutic drugs. This appears to raise some conflict with the joint statement made on 13 September 1987 in a Press release issued by Senator Button and by Dr Blewett when they announced measures to encourage greater Australian investment in the pharmaceutical industry. The Government policy, announced on 13 September, provided encouragement for manufacturers to invest further in Australia. It did this by making certain concessions. The first was to promise to extend the patent life of Australian Drug Evaluation Committee approved products by a further four years. The second was that the joint Press release of 13 September promised to create a pricing authority which will consider Australia's activity as an important criterion in setting prices. That was the promise of 13 September. The industry understood that to mean that if there were Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing activity that would be a factor which would be taken into account in a favourable way by a new pricing authority to be appointed by the Government. That is the only possible interpretation of that joint Press release. Of course it was an industry Press release.

The announcements made in the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 are simply not consistent, because the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), having been party to that joint Press release, announced as part of the Budget package the proposed amendments to the terms of reference of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee which we are considering tonight. The proposal we are considering tonight can lead to only one thing: lower prices to the pharmaceutical manufacturers for Australian goods. So what is it going to be? Is it the provision in this Bill to contain and reduce prices, or is it the provision announced in the joint Press statement of 13 September which held out some hope and promise to the industry of some better times ahead?

This is important. The pharmaceutical manufacturing industry should remain active in Australia, because of the economic activity which it generates, because of the employment which it generates and also because of the strategic importance which it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —And its research-based activity.

—My colleague Senator Watson says because of its research-based activity. Some of it is in research-based activity. We and the Department of Community Services and Health know that the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry has been contracting steadily over the last 10 years and shedding labour and we have become more and more a country which imports its pharmaceutical drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators of what happened in World War I-some time ago-when this country suddenly discovered that its supplies of some medication were cut off. It was during that time that the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry emerged. It was research based, as Senator Watson reminded us earlier, and of course it was the early discovery and work in the area of salicylates in this country under the spur of war and supply interruption that established pharmaceutical manufacturing in this country. I want the Government to tell us whether it wants a pharmaceutical manufacturing industry or whether it wants us to become a drug importing country. It is perfectly possible for that to happen.

I once visited an American pharmacological company in Skokie, Illinois. The Department of Community Services and Health will be able to identify the company straight away. There was an enormous office building. The people said: `We make an oral contraceptive. Do you want to see where we make it?'. They took me to a window on the thirteenth floor and pointed down and said: `See that little hut down there, that is where the world's supply of our oral contraceptive is made'. They could supply the world from that tiny manufacturing plant. The question I ask is: Why would these large companies bother to maintain any manufacturing capacity in this country? If they do not, what will be the consequences for Australia? There will be many. Unless the Government can give really clear answers to these contradictory statements which have emerged the industry will not have the confidence in its future that it should have.

I raised this mater during the Estimates examination of the Department of Community Services and Health. I have to say, in defence of officers of the Department, that I have been giving the following answer:

In our discussions with the industry we pointed out one approach that might be taken to this new Australian activity criterion in setting prices. We suggested it could take the form of a price premium over a floor price, the floor price being determined on the basis of other criteria. If that is the approach that is taken the price premium could be set independently of the PBAC's recommendations, taking cost effectiveness into account.

That is a very fair answer. It is not for the officers to give the policy answer on behalf of the Government. So I ask the Government now: What is its policy approach? Will it take that approach which was offered to me by an officer? Will the Government identify the price premium over the floor price? Will the Government not just tell us, but tell the industry, what is going to be done? Will the price premium be set independently of the PBAC's recommendations, as the officer indicated was possible? He said one approach might be possible. Is that the approach which the Government is going to take? What the industry wants to know is: What is going to happen to it?

While I thank the officer for the answer I was given in the Estimates Committee hearing, we now need from the Government some confirmation of the road down which it will travel, and we want that confirmation merely so we can know whether we will continue to have a pharmaceutical manufacturing industry, and really those of us who are consumers of pharmaceuticals occasionally want to know what our future will be. I hope the Minister will explain in more detail how this will operate. Will he explain in detail why two statements were allowed to come out, which have created such confusion and concern in the industry? I also hope the Minister will clarify the Government's policy. Is it a policy concerned solely with cost cutting in relation to therapeutic drugs?

TALK.START.PARA: —It sure is.

—Senator Walters says that it sure is. But we can ask the Government, as a matter of good faith: Will some greater costs be accepted to encourage investment in the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry? If so, please tell us on what basis and which Press release or which statement we should accept?

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the last two measures, which will help ensure speedier payment of pharmaceutical benefits-the so-called Pharmpay system. Over the last year the Government has tried to clean up what has been a very unsatisfactory situation. As a senator for New South Wales I have found it very distressing to have to make repeated representations on behalf of pharmacists who are in considerable financial difficulty solely because the Government has failed to pay to them money which it owes. Senator Puplick referred to a delay of 102 days. I am not allowed to have that kind of delay in my commercial transactions in the community, so why should the Government? Why should pharmacists have to carry that kind of load?

What kind of administration allows a backlog of 51 million prescriptions? The Department gave me some answers which said that a year ago there were some matters beyond its control, such as illness among keyboard staff. But it is the Government's job, when it has introduced a regulatory mechanism, to make that mechanism work, and a backlog of 51 million prescriptions is not acceptable. If pharmacists are, or were, going to the wall because the Government was unable to process their claims and unable to pay them what it owed them, that is a disgrace. It has been just one of the many disgraces which have operated in this area for too long. If the Government is now proposing some mechanisms, which look as though they may enable prompt and efficient payment of accounts from pharmacists, I welcome these. I welcome the methods of speeding up payment. The use of modern technology, the use of modems and floppy disks, seems to me to have much to commend it. If the extra premium to which Senator Puplick referred is associated with a reduction in administrative cost, that will be worth while.

I have raised several matters in this contribution to the debate. I have asked the Minister to respond to several of them and I hope that the Minister, in summing up this debate, will answer what are very serious questions in relation to a Bill involving very serious matters.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory: Public Telex Message Service

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telecom Australia is in the process of rationalising the public telex message service throughout Australia. In the Northern Territory Telecom has restricted the hours of operation at the Darwin Telecom message bureau since 17 October. This restriction in effect means that messages can now be lodged during the office hours of 8.30 a.m. to 4.30 p.m., Monday to Friday. Of course, Telecom advises that lodgment and delivery will continue to be provided on a 24-hour basis from another Telecom message bureau. Where is that bureau? Of course it is outside the Northern Territory, which means that interstate telephone calls are involved in lodging one's public telex message in order to get it through. Telecom has also announced that the service will be withdrawn entirely in the Northern Territory on 30 January 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: So, by pulling out public telex, obviously Telecom has made some sort of assessment that people living in remote areas of Australia do not need access to this sort of communication. I would like to ask: Is the Government convinced that the alteration and cancellation of the public telex facility is warranted, particularly in remote areas such as the Northern Territory where there are inadequate alternative arrangements in place and where, quite frankly, a serious disruption will be caused to communications services? Also, what about the Telecom staff, the people who man these bureaus? I am aware that some of the staff have been there for 20 or 30 years. They will suddenly be told by Telecom, `If you want a job in a continuing area, transfer somewhere interstate'. I think that is heartless, inadequate and very poor planning. I would ask the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is at the table, to please draw this matter to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in order that he can undertake a review of what I consider to be a draconian and unnecessary Telecom action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I was expecting Senator Puplick to say something else today.
—Is that an invitation? I am quite prepared to oblige.

—No, the honourable senator has missed his opportunity. Senator Tambling raised the question of rationalisation of public telex services in the Northern Ter- ritory. I am not sure whether Senator Tambling and I will agree very often, but I must admit that the issue he raised is one with which I have some reasonable degree of sympathy because in north Queensland I have been making representations to Telecom Australia about similar rationalisation procedures. So across the chamber we might find that we have some agreement now and then.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly I can understand the honourable senator's concern about the rationalisation as it affects the people of the Northern Territory immediately. But the situation, as the honour- able senator describes it, will be of more concern as of 30 January. I will ask the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, to respond to Senator Tambling in relation to his call for a review. Certainly I know that there are many people in isolated areas who are very concerned about some of the cutbacks in Telecom services, and I have been making representations along similar lines.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that official passports and diplomatic passports are insufficient proof of identity for the issuing of a normal passport; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is correct that an official or diplomatic passport is not acceptable proof of identity for the issue of an ordinary passport.

An ordinary passport issued after 1 July 1983 can be used as proof of citizenship (but not identity) for the issue of another passport. Identity is established by interview, supporting evidence, and the formal Certificate Regarding Applicant.

Diplomatic and official passports are issued for a restricted period at the request of the sponsoring Department or authority, and applicants neither undergo interview nor produce full documentation. They have not, therefore, established their eligibility for a full 10-year validity ordinary passport.
These remarks describe the current procedure. The procedure is, however, now under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware that changes made to the W. A. Workers' Compensation and Assistance Act late in 1986 have had the effect of transferring the responsibility for long-term income maintenance in respect of totally and permanently disabled workers in W.A. from the Government of W.A. and the W.A. State Government Insurance Commission to the Federal Department of Social Security.

(2) Does the Federal Government accept that it is appropriate for the Government of Western Australia and its insurer to thus escape their liability for injured workers and, if not, what measures will the Minister take to correct the situation.
(3) How many intraspinal injections were given in the year 1986 at the pain clinics at the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital and the Royal Perth Hospital for the treatment of chronic back pain.
(4) How many patients were involved.
(5) How many of these treatments involved the use of the drug Depomedrol or of the same drug sold under any other trade name.
(6) What proportion of these treatments were ceased before the full series of injections had been given.
(7) Were the patients involved routinely warned of possible side effects of this treatment, including the possibility of chronic adhesive arachnoiditis.
(8) Were the patients concerned monitored closely after treatment.

(9) In how many cases were adverse reactions to the administration of Depomedrol by epidural/intradural or intrathecal injection noted and in how many cases were the adverse effects notified to the Adverse Drug Reaction Committee.
(10) How many of the patients who received Depomedrol by such injection were undergoing treatment related to a claim for workers compensation.

(11) Will the Minister confirm that the manufacturers of Depomedrol, Upjohn Pty Ltd and Astra Phar- maceuticals, supply warnings with the drug stating that it is contra-indicated for injection into the spine because of crippling and debilitating complications which have been reported.

(12) Will the Minister further confirm that administration of Depomedrol by intrathecal and epidural injection ceased at the St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney because of serious adverse reactions by 1981 or earlier.
(13) Can the Minister advise whether this preparation is still being used in any other States this way.
(14) What steps will the Minister take to ensure that administration of Depomedrol by intraspinal injection ceases forthwith in W.A.
(15) What steps does the Minister propose to take to make it mandatory for doctors to report adverse drug reactions to the Adverse Drug Reaction Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Minister for Social Security has advised that the changes made to the W.A. Workers' Compensation and Assistance Act in late 1986 may involve a reduction in the liability of employers/ insures in Western Australia. However, present indications are that the effects are likely to be small.

The Government does not accept that it is appropriate that liability for injuries to workers should be transferred from insurers to the social security system, and the Department of Social Security is currently monitoring the effects of changes in States' legislation in this area.
It should also be noted that recent amendments to Social Security provisions for those receiving compensation payments will reduce opportunities to transfer costs.
(3) to (8), (10), (13) and (14) I am not able to comment on the matters raised in these questions as the Commonwealth does not monitor or control the use of marketed drugs by the States.

(9) The Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (ADRAC) gives an explicit undertaking that identities of patients, reporters and institutions will remain confidential. Thus, information relating to a particular clinic cannot be divulged. For the whole of Australia, between 1 November 1972 and 31 March 1987 ADRAC received 38 reports of suspected adverse reactions to Depo-Medrol. Sixteen of these involved intrathecal or epidural administration and fifteen of these described arachnoiditis.

(11) I am advised that the warning on the product (which is manufactured by Upjohn) in the 1987 Prescription Products Guide does not contraindicate its use for injection into the spine, but says instead that ``Depo-Medrol is not recommended for intrathecal administration''. Also, under the Adverse Reactions section, printed in bold type is the statement, ``arachnoiditis has been reported following intrathecal administration''.

(12) The Commonwealth does not monitor the use of marketed drugs by the States. However, I note that in a letter published in the Medical Journal of Australia on 19 September 1981, Dr David Gibb, Staff Specialist in the Department of Anaesthetics of St. Vincent's Hospital, stated that the use of intraspinal steroid injections had been discontinued.

(15) ADRAC favours the active encouragement of voluntary reporting of suspected adverse reactions in preference to mandatory reporting by doctors. In the light of ADRAC's position I am not proposing to take any steps towards the introduction of a mandatory system at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which office holders in the Department of Veterans' Affairs have authority to give the initial Departmental approval of the referral of a patient by a medical practitioner to a clinical psychologist.
(2) Are these office holders appointed by written delegation; if so, by whom; if not, what method of appointment is used.

(3) What professional qualifications are held by Departmental personnel who are the incumbents of those offices; in particular, did the person in the N.S.W. Branch Office who gave or withheld approvals in 1984 to 1986 have any qualifications or experience in clinical psychology; if so, what are the details.

(4) When initial approval is given for referral, does that approval specify the number of sessions with the clinical psychologist; if so: (a) how many sessions are specified; (b) how does the approving authority ascertain the appropriate number of sessions; and (c) if further sessions are considered to be needed by the clinical psychologist treating the patient how does the approving authority judge whether these additional services should be approved.
(5) Does the approving authority give reasons to (a) the general practitioner; and (b) the clinical psychologist, for his decision to approve or reject proposals; if not, why not.

(6) Has the responsibility of the Departmental officials for failure to approve clinical psychologist sessions resulting in subsequent claims or charges of neglect or professional incompetence been considered; if so, what were the results of those considerations; if not, why not.

(7) (a) Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs table a copy of the ``Treatment Principles'' prepared under the provisions of Section 90 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; (b) on what date did those ``Treatment Principles'' become effective and when and in what form were they promulgated to (i) the Parliament, (ii) general practitioners, (iii) clinical psychologists, and (iv) veterans' organisations; and (c) what were the rules relevant to ``prior approvals'' before the effective date of those ``Treatment Principles'' and what was the legislative authority for those rules.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Deputy Commissioners, Managers of Treatment Sections and their senior staff hold delegations to approve referrals to clinical psychologists.
(2) Yes. The authority to approve referrals has been delegated to these officers by the Repatriation Commission under sub-section 213 (1) of the Veterans' Entitlement Act.

(3) Delegates would not normally hold professional qualifications relevant to the allied health professional area. They have responsibilities additional to those involved in exercising delegated authority. These responsibilities include eligibility checking, communication with providers and patients, etc.

Administrative guidelines require that professional advice be obtained from either a Departmental Medical Officer or a Departmentally employed consultant in the discipline under consideration. Referrals for treatment by psychologists are usually submitted to the Senior Specialist (Psychiatry) for recommendation. The delegate acts on the basis of that advice.

(4) (a) (b) and (c) The approval for treatment by a clinical psychologist specifies the duration and frequency of sessions based on the advice of the Senior Specialist (Psychiatry) and varies depending on the circumstances of each case. Where additional sessions are required the treating psychologist will normally provide a written report in support of the request which is then referred to the Senior Specialist (Psychiatry) for recommendation.

(5) (a) and (b) Reasons are not generally given unless the approval is different from that requested. Where a request is declined, reasons as advised by the psychiatrist are provided to the referring medical officer or to the clinical psychologist.

(6) The arrangements which are followed are considered to be satisfactory. Officers responsible for deciding requests for treatment by psychologists have access to professional advice. No instances have come to notice where a request for services has been declined which has resulted in charges of neglect or professional incompetence.

(7) (a) Pursuant to S.90 (6) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Treatment Principles were tabled in both Houses on 19 August 1986. Instruments varying the Treatment Principles have been tabled on 11 November 1986 and 17 February 1987.
(i) See answer to 7 (a) above.
(ii) The Treatment Principles is a public document;

(iii) and (iv) copies are available through the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS). Ex-service organisations and the major provider organisations were issued with copies. Local Medical Officers (LMOs) were advised of the Principles through the LMO Newsletter.
(c) The prior approval requirements referred to in the Treatment Principles are not new. Regulation 68 of the now repealed Repatriation Regulations stated:
``The Commission shall not be liable for any expenditure incurred without its authority in respect of medical treatment of a person.''

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what authority is the Interdepartmental Committee on fees and allowances for clinical fees and allowances for clinical psychologists established.
(2) Are clinical psychologists salaried professionals, do they contract their services to the Commonwealth, or what other arrangements exist for the provision of their services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Interdepartmental Committee on Fees and Allowances was established in 1949 by the then Prime Minister, the Right Honourable J. B. Chifley. (2) My Department employs clinical psychologists in Repatriation Hospitals, as salaried professionals under the Public Service Act. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Private Secretary to Minister for Veterans' Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a Jeremy Gilling, Private Secretary, write on 20 January 1987 to Mr Petroni and did he state ``As Senator Gietzelt is presently on leave, I am replying on his behalf''.

(2) Was the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, on leave; if so: (a) had another Minister been appointed to act for him during his absence on leave; if not, why not; and (b) if so, which Minister was appointed and why did the Private Secretary and not the acting Minister sign the letter.

(3) Did the Private Secretary state that: ``I have received a report from the New South Wales Branch office and am satisfied that they have acted fairly and reasonable''; if so: (a) what qualifications or experience did the Private Secretary have to be able to express an opinion about whether the actions were fair or reasonable; (b) what authority can be attached to such an expression of opinion by a Private Secretary; and (c) if the Private Secretary had no such authority what action has been taken to (i) establish an appropriate authority and (ii) take disciplinary action with respect to the Private Secretary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October 1987 (Hansard, page 793) Senator Teague asked me a question without notice concerning the revenue which will be raised by the higher education administration charge and by postgraduate fees in 1988. He also asked whether the Government has approved `the full fee approach of the new Bond University in Queensland'. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Gross revenue raised by the higher education administration charge in 1988 will be an estimated $105.4 million (1988 outturn prices) and institutions will continue to retain 10% of the revenue derived from the charge. Net revenue to the Commonwealth, after allowing for 10% retention by institutions and reimbursement by the Commonwealth for certain categories of students, such as student assistance scheme beneficiaries and subsidised overseas students, is likely to be of the order of $64 million in 1988.

The Government has decided to allow a limited relaxation of the prohibition on fees for certain postgraduate courses from 1988. Courses for which fees may be charged are those for students already in employment who are upgrading or updating their qualifications. Students proceeding to postgraduate study direct from undergraduate courses will not be required to pay fees.

This initiative will enable institutions to be more responsive to the needs of the economy and to offer expensive specialised courses which may have not been viable in the past. Formal applications to charge fees have not been sought from institutions at this stage, and no estimates are yet available of income likely to be generated. The revenue raised by this measure will be retained by institutions, and the Commonwealth will not reduce its grants on account of revenue generated from fees.
As the Bond University is a private institution which does not receive funding from the Commonwealth its fees policy is essentially a matter for it to determine.

The Commonwealth's involvement has been limited to approving its development under foreign investment policy and to approving it for full fee overseas students. The Bond University, a joint venture between the Bond Corporation and a Japanese company, was established under an Act of the Queensland Parliament. It received Foreign Investment Review Board approval on the understanding that no requests will be made for Commonwealth support.

It is the Government's policy to encourage the export of education services, providing certain conditions are met, and the Bond University has been placed on the Register of Full Fee Courses for overseas students. This means that, subject to usual conditions, students enrolled at the University will be eligible to gain a student entry visa to Australia.
